content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								I desperately wanted to give this a No, given that it's comming from the company that lost any possible claim of credibility with Early Access games, but I just can't.I was a big DF fan, for the games they had done before, and for keep on innovating on their smaller Amnesia'ed games. I even went personaly to their offices and gave Tim a framed fan art[dl.dropboxusercontent.com], and got The Art of Brutal Legend signed by the team, and a Brutal Legend box signed by Tim, so you could say I was a "fan-boy". But I didn't much care for Broken Age, as I think it devolved the genre rather than evolve it - I'm sure the next logical step is to keep bringing the number of interactions down, so it will go from one to zero, and the game will just play by itself...But then the DF-9 fiasco brought down my fan-boydom overnight. I understand the logic they were working on, but a lot of people today simply no longer buy Early Access games, and were waiting for the game to come out. I was one of those people, and now they'll never see that money. So I believe that any loss they would incur now during development would be made up after relase, but now not only did they severely hurt their prospects with any future Early Access games (and Kickstarters too, I'm sure), they've managed to further distance most players from Early Access titles (which I'm not overly concerned as a player, but as a developer with an Early Access title on Steam myself, this affects me personaly, so color me biased...).That said, this game is VERY good and deserves your attention. The art style oozes personality, and the strategy layer that takes place between missions is very deep and engaging. If you get too attached to your fighters you will be disappointed, as if they don't die in the battlefield, they'll die of old age. But that's a good thing and not a bad thing like some reviews here state - you can't possibly be interested in a game for it's multi-generational layer, and then complain that your squad is not made of Methuselahs that live 500 years. Fighter recycling is at the very core of the game here.Another great thing is that you'll have some very tough decisions regarding were you allocate each of your peoples. They can be fighting, but they can also be assigned as:- Regents and their partners make new heroes and pass their traits on.- Scholars decrease building and 'science' time- Defaults give XP and other bonuses to heroes.(I don't think these are the proper names, but that's the gist of it)You want your best people on these roles in order to keep improving and have better heroes in the future, but you want your best heroes in your squad to fight the missions and not get slaughtered.The tactical battles are good but not great. Yes, X-Com is a better game on this regard, and if this is all your care in a game of this type, then by all means, install the Long War mod and avoid this game. I for one like to have a deeper strategy layer, and I think Massive Chalice beats X-Com in that regard. Given this game's budget compared to X-Com's, I think 1-for-1 is pretty darn good. Is it an inferior X-Com clone? Most certainly not, as it does a LOT of things differently, both in the tactical battles (even if I personally don't like them), and specially on the strategy layer.My two biggest complains with it so far:1. This game requires a decent ammount of min-maxing to make good decisions on the things I mentioned earlier. This is not a bad thing on itself, I enjoy min-maxing games, but it does lack features that allow you to min-max efficiently, like robust tools to sort, filter and compare heroes stats and traits.2. Alchemists frequently do something like this:


YouTube™ Video: Almost Murked Her Whole Class: Female Police Trainee Throws A Grenade The Wrong Way! REBLOP.COM 

			Views: 243,137		

			Almost Murked Her Whole Class: Female Police Trainee Throws A Grenade The Wrong Way! Brazilian female cop trainee throws a grenade the wrong way, into a crowd of her fellow classmates...		

I'm waiting for the official release to keep playing more, specially due to my first issue there. That said, if the worst came to happen and the developer just walked away today (it's certainly not a far-fetched idea...), I think the game already delivers it's full price in entertainment value as it is. That's why it gets a Yes from me, no matter how much I wanted to not like it.By the way, if you've read this far, I'm going to plug my game I mentioned earlier. Behold, the Adventurezator:I'm working on a loss too during Early Access BTW, but I assure you that you won't see me throw my hands in the air and give up because of this.And if you are curious about the art I mentioned earlier, it's from the intro cutscene for this game (you can watch it on the store page)

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is still early access at time of review.  I've completed my first playthrough in ~15-18 hours, I believe.Overall, I really like this game because it provides consistently difficult choices which are only going to last a short while before you have to make even more. I should have restarted once I got the hang of everything because you're semi-pigeonholed once you're up and running with the initial choices - however I won and it was fun seeing how far I could get and seeing what I can do with it all.There's a really big timeline which I believe is ~300 years. The ultimate goal is to hold off the monsters for 300 years until the Chalice can do something epic and cleanse the monsters (the Cadence) forever(?). Any time you need a building/research/item for your people/weapon/armor to be made you can only pick 1 of those things. Often research takes anywhere from 5-20 years and you cannot research anything else during that time. You can only hit the "fastforward" button on the timeline and hope nothing bad goes down. Once something occurs the game pauses and you can deal with it, whether it's research or an attack on your lands.You've got heroes from different houses and you appoint a male and female regent & partner so they can create offspring. The templates of their traits and tendencies for stats come together and create children that are then trained to be fighters. Your characters are constantly dying from battle but more often from old age, and you have to continually supply new ones to keep things running smoothly. The big battle here is to make sure you appoint people who are very fertile with good stats so you can supply enough for upkeep. You can sacrifice 7 years to recruit new heroes. Deaths of any kind are permanent in here. It's actually a tad depressing, because I actually found Brad Muir (Thed esigner) as a character and watched him grow old and die.The combat itself is very reminiscent to a partially simplified XCOM which is not a bad thing at all. It provides challenge from the get-go, with enemies that you absolutely do not want to get close (they'll explode, they reduce your XP on hit, or their melee makes you 5 years older every swing), enemies that keep their distance and snipe, or enemies that create other enemies and you're in a mad dash to kill them so the flow of creatures stops.You can save and load throughout your timeline so there's no real pressure if you make a terrible mistake - you can load an older save you'll get an entirely different scenario all together. This is a bit of a player crutch but it's not unwelcomed since I'm 7 hours in and I'm still not through the whole timeline..The art is cool and the UI is fairly basic in a good way. All you really see is the damage spread you'll do and the amount of HP left on the creature. Moving and attacking are fairly simple.Characters in your ranks gain abilities as they level, each one being a "one or the other" choice down the chain. I've never gotten down the entire chain before dying of old age, so I don't know what some of them do.The classes are hunter (ranged stealth DEX), caberjack (melee, knockback tank STR), and alchemist (mid-ranged finite amount of bombs being thrown --- honestly this class seems to be a bit weak, I can't find anything very good about it. INT). You deploy up to 5 at a time, and really, less than 5 heroes is often going to be a tough challenge.I just bring hunters and caberjacks due to the types of enemies I've been encountering. I generally don't want them anywhere near me so I just try to snipe them all before they close any ground. I also like using the hunters to go invisible and scout out the territory so I know how I want to set up.  You can lead enemies into traps if you just set up your hunters and have the caberjack as bait.So yeah, totally pleased with my purchase on this one. It's got its kinks, especially if you've appointed characters of different ages offset in such a way that it'll keep stopping you and asking you to appoint people to thrones or roles. Stop, transition animation into building, click on a guy from a list, exit from menu, fastforward on timeline (repeat x5). The kinks, though, especially for an Early Access title are very small and the overall thing has felt solid.And yeah, the art is solid and simple. The environments have breakables/exploding stuff/hazards. It looks good.A word of warning at the time of writing - DO NOT TRY TO WIN THIS GAME.  THE ENDING IS CURRENTLY IN FLUX AND IT WILL MURDER YOUUUUUU.   Check my screenshot to see my experience there  :)

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Heyyo, I was a Massive Chalice Kickstarter backer after having seen the fantastic pitch video. :)Double Fine has delivered on their promises of Massive Chalice. It's turn-based strategy, permadeath, bloodlines, relics and strategy where you play as a ruler who is immortal and guides his people in a war that spans 300 years.So as a ruler? You get chalise-attuned heroes which means not just any pesant can join your ranks. You can aquire them from mating your heroes in keeps via bloodlines which at random of a hero death may lead to a bloodline-tied relic, an extra-strong piece of equipment that gains effectiveness as the hero it is equipped to gains experience... So you're constantly balancing researching new technologies, building keeps/sage towers or Crucibles (for boosting experience points of your heroes per day by dedicated a hero as a Standard Bearer). Plus? You can't forget about random events... oh yes, they are random, interesting and both rewarding or dangerous. ;)I'm only on my first playthrough and have made some bad choices and have been paying for them... but it has taught me that no two playthroughs are the same and this game is definitely a gem. I definitely intend to do more playthroughs after waiting for a few patches and changes to the game.Right now? It's on patch 0.85 and is pretty fun. There is a few balance issues with the game... namely Hunters (the archerer class) is overpowered compared to the other classes. I found using 4 Hunters and 1 Alchemist (a potion-based warriror/mage class... thingy or something lol) was the most efficient team of heroes to use in combat. Mainly because the Caberjack (melee warrior class) has several disadvantages due to the unique properties of the Cadence (the evil forces of the game). For example, Wrinklers are an enemy type that does melee damage and causes aging effects if they hit you... but with a team of Hunters and Alchemist? You can usually take them out before they get close to you... Lapse's are an enemy that cause your characters to lose their memories (experience points in this case) and when they die? They explode and cause minor damage to anyone nearby but also there's a risk of getting stunned... Rupture's are suicide units and wether they die or kamikazi? They explode and do minor damage but lower armor effectiveness (called armor corruption). All three of these enemy types can be easily dispatched from a safe distance. Debateable? But you can research and equip Wünderpants to negate the aging and memory-loss attacks of the Wrinklers and Lapsers... but it takes up the only item slot they get which means no health potions or Max HP buffs and they can still damage you or stun you... so once again, better from a safe distance. Plus, if they get close? Alchemists are decent melee units... so I always sent any camberjacks I recruited to the Sage Tower (helps lower research time) or as a regent's partner for breeding.So yeah... Massive Chalice is a darn fun game, but it does need a little patch refining to especially make Camberjacks more effective... they need a bigger healthpoint pool and dare I say more than one inventory slot for acessories out of the gate. Upgraded? Camberjacks are pretty handy... but they usually have an average Hitpoint pool just like the other classes and that's not good when they're supposed to be in the front lines taking abuse.. and abuse they shall take.

												Recommended for fans of tactics/RPG games, though I suggest getting it during a sale as it is shorter and not as in-depth as some other games in the genre like XCOM or FFTactics.+Decent variety of character classes/subclasses, abilities, weapons/armor/items, enemies+Voice acting and writing/commentary by characters is well done+Tactical battles require some thoughtful planning and ability use+Several options outside of battles for developing and managing the different territories and bloodlines you choose-Camera in battle isn't very smooth-Relatively short (~10-15hrs) compared to other similar games, overall story is sparse-May not be as approachable for players new to this type of game-Can't grow attached to any particular characters as none will ever remain for all too long

Posted: June 14, 2015
												It's difficult to fully recommend this game. I've waffled between thumbs up and down. If it's on a 50% sale, it'd be a good buy.The combat is good, but it's largely the same thing over and over. You and the monsters get more powerful, but the monsters don't change. You change some due to the skills chosen. Terrain is overly simplistic. There's no cover rules and the terrain variation is very limited. Managing bloodlines is interesting, but if you do it poorly you don't realize it's a lost game until much, much later. In some ways that's good as your decisions have long term impact. In other ways, it's bad as you invest a lot of time in a lost cause before it's clear the game can't be won. It's almost a good game.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												Your kingdom is dying. The Cadence - a pestilence, an army of monsters, an evil slime mold - is closing in around you. And the only thing you can do is trust in the wisdom of two disembodied advisers talking to you out of a large cup/fountain. They're telling you that the Cadence can be beat. It'll only take three hundred years and men and women of noble blood to fight the good fight. You'll see families turn into dynasties, the clumsy 'slow learner' turn into Lydia 'the Rose' Kendrick, your most formidable alchemist, and all the while, the rotting of your nation will continue. The outer regions will fall and heroes will die. All to the accompaniment of a soundtrack that's appropriately mournful, graphics that are appropriately understated (though I will admit a little more variety in the character models would've gone a long way) and surprisingly engaging voice work.Massive Chalice isn't perfect, and I don't think it holds up well to multiple playthroughs. But as someone who's not particularly good at tactics games, and whose poor decisions early on made even a 'normal' difficulty game really harrowing around the year 150, this game's tone, aesthetic and the actual difficulties I was facing came together in a super memorable way.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
Strategy-lite,  XCOM combat style, accelerated time, dynastic marriage systemOn the one hand, Massive Chalice uses squad based combat similar to XCOM. On the other, you breed new heroes by arranging marriages (kind of like Crusader Kings 2). The traits of the parents, good or bad, can pass on to the children. Producing children is vital because in-game time passes quickly. Battles occur about every 10 years, thus your combat squad composition changes nearly every fight as heroes die naturally. Overall, I think it's a decent strategy game for different types of personality. If you are the micromanaging type, you can spend a lot of time looking at character sheets to optimize marriages and squad selection. If you are a casual player, the game is forgiving and does not have a lot of complexity. There are only a dozen or so enemy units which get tougher.The art style may not be for everyone. The game sort of looks like if you turned the graphic settings to the lowest, giving everything a slightly geometric, block-like quality. This is by design, makes it unique but I can see it turning some people off. However, the use of color is amazing and to me, made the game visually memorable.

number of helpful: 38 of 77 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
Early Access Review
Started playing and couldn't stop.Here's the breakdown:Graphics (9/10)Loved the blocky look of the units, landscape, and map. It made me think of a stained-glass window come to life and worked very well for a medieval setting. The drastic diffences in the look of armor and weapons (especially the heirloom weapons) added to the unique look of the units.Audio (6/10):While the music was nice and the dialogue was humorous, I found myself listening to the comments of the narrators repeat over and over again early on in the game (about 1/3 of the way through). The voice acting itself was good, though the female actor clearly understood the witty dialogue better.Gameplay (9/10)The best compliment to pay the game is that it is very similar to XCOM: Enemy Unknown in its turn-based combat. The political parts of the game added a lot to the time between battle -- putting emphasis on makin' babies (the more children you have = the more units you have and the more options you have for putting specific people in specific positions of power). Battles gradually got harder as the story neared its 300-year mark, causing new enemy types to appear battle after battle, though I never felt like the game gave me more than I could handle. One issue that I ran into was that I could completely exploit the Alchemist units and by the end of the game could have a squad of fully-upgraded Alchemists who could wipe the floor with their almost OP abilities. Especially since the last mission allows you to continually refill your flasks.Story (7/10)Watching 300 years of a country pass by while I attempted to save it from unknown baddies really emersed me in the world and, although the story is as simple as that, made it feel quite real. Seeing generation after generation of the rulers die out and pass on their legacies made the story unique as it was no about one person or family, but about a country and its survival. Sadly, the ending left me wanting and didn't quite live up to all the work I put into these families. Also, though there were many random events that took place between battles involving non-combat confrontations with the citizens of the country, I felt like there could have been many more of them than I experianced.Replayability (7/10)Getting to choose what families ruled the country gave the game some replayability (especially if you choose the humorous name option), just so you can see what names might come up (one of my proudest warriors was named Slippy Goatbone). Spec'ing out your units in different ways allows you to play the game differently at least few times, emphasizing certain units, skills, or research in order to try out different strategies. The way the game ends makes me think that a second playthrough might have some different dialogue from the main characters, although I haven't started my second playthrough yet.Total: 7.6/10MASSIVE CHALICE Main Website[www.massivechalice.com] MASSIVE CHALICE Wiki[massivechalice.gamepedia.com]

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								***UPDATED***POST RELEASE REVIEW:I've played this game in early access, decided that I don't like it at current state, but was sure that it had much potential and release will change a lot. And it didn't.While Double Fine has added class shuffling and improved graphics a bit, game's main disadvantages (in my eyes) are still there - the HUGE dependance on luck factor, lack of depth in battle missions and unappealing maps and models. I officially regret that I have backed this game up on Kickstarter. This will be a lesson to me, not to back concepts that has nothing to show but idea. Ideas can be great, but bad realisation can ruin any great idea. I hope you will learn from my mistake. ORIGINAL PRE-RELEASE REVIEW:Now a little bit more detailes:My main complaint is luck factor. There is a LOT about luck in this game, from the begining, traits of your heroes are random and while it's not difficult at first to play with idiots, drunkards and slowpokes, the biggest problem is that you have to apoint one of these genetic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to start a bloodline, meaning he/she will pass down all the bad traits and habbits across generations for at least 50 years or so. Then you have random events - they can cripple your only good heroes or even kill them. Good choices are not even remotely as rewarding. Defend missions may have♥♥♥♥♥♥for reward, and if you are unlucky, the same zones will be attacked and eventually regardless of what you do, you will start to loose land and buildings that you have puted so much time to build.And finally luck on the battlefield is a huge factor - starting from position (you can start with all heroes being surrounded) and finishing with misses. Even the veterans can miss, especially if they were bred by genetic trash you had to put up with at the begining of the game. And while it's not always lethal, with each hero you loose, your macro economy will get cripled a lot. The only existing remedy to this is load after each huge fail, but that is a gameplay killer for me. Now don't get me wrong - I'm not saying the game is too hard or impossible. It's just frustrating. Also there is very little depth in the whole mechanics, but I really hope that it's just the matter of time. Basically, you don't have to be a smart strategist to play this game as long as you have good heroes, simply because all correct things to do are obvious and there isn't a lot of things you need to do but wait. Combined with luck factor this is really bad, because it's the depth and smart unobvious choices that are supposed to balance bad luck you have to face with, and this game doesn't have the any of that.The final problem I see in this game is it's graphics - while it does have certain unique style to it, the models are so poor on polygons, I don't understad why have developers made this in 3D - the game obciously could have been 2D with MUCH more appeal. I'm sad to say this, but heroes models look ugly, Double Fine have been cuting budget to 3D modelers waaay too much. Now this problem isn't big for me, the good gameplay always comes first, but it's certainly a letdown.Heroes are the only (except for the Challice) alive characters in this game that you can see, but being faceless and almost featureless makes them very hard to think of as characters, instead of skill sets.

number of helpful: 85 of 172 people (49%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a fan of XCOM I was very exited when this game got funded on kickstarter, I only realised a few days ago that the game was actually available for download. I've played the crap out of it over the last few days and I've got to say for the most part I've really enjoyed it. The presentation and style of the game is great, it looks beautiful and has a quirky sense of humor. The character classes are distinct but lacking, as there are only three. Caberjack (melee), Hunter (ranged), and Alchemist (mix of both), although this is set to change with an upcoming patch which will allow players to mix classes. The gameplay is fun, although it did begin to feel a little repetitive by the end of the game. I really enjoyed the bloodlines aspect of the game which gave you the chance to marry different heroes with the hope of creating offspring with the best traits of their parents (this was a little tricky but very enjoyable when done right). If your heroes went through several grueling battles and distinguished themselves there was the chance that their weapon would become an heirloom, basically a special weapon that leveled up over the campaign. One of my favourite moments in the game came when a young alchemist named Seargent Ra became my first level 6 character after two battles. With his amazing stats I decided to name Seargent as the next reagent of the house Ra, now Standard had the ‘bountiful’ trait, allowing him to basically have kids in litters. The guy ended up having nine kids and established the Ra lineage as the dominant family in my game. That wasn’t enough for Seargent, when the magnificent ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ died he left his weapon behind which became the first heirloom in my game. Two of his ancestors fought in my final battle many generations later, one of them carrying his weapon, the ‘Inevitable’. This is exactly why I bought this game, I wanted a story behind my heroes, I wanted to feel this connection to the characters. The main issue I had that it did get repetitive by end game and I didn’t have as much of a connection with the heroes as I originally did. However I still enjoyed the experience.On the whole this is still very much a work in progress but I’ve really enjoyed it so far.

number of helpful: 14 of 29 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
Product received for free
												I don't like Double Fine, I think they're a cut-corners type of shop. I also don't like Tim Schafer, I think he's a over-appreciated ♥♥♥♥♥♥. I love turn based combat and strategic games, though. You can check my hours played in Crusader Kings 2 and you will know that this game about building dynasties across the realm is right up my alley. If it had come from another studio I probably would have bought it much sooner.I won this game in a give-away and I was very excited to actually get to give it a shot. I refuse to spend any more money on DF products (I bought DF9 and backed Broken Age, blech) but a Fire Emblem knock off should be fun and engaging even if it's made by a substance over style group.So, anyway, enough about my experiences and feelings, what aboutThe actual gameIt's ugly. The "style" is very low-fi and legitimately looks like the shaders and textures didn't all load. It's not consistent, some random objects look way out of place and the particle effects are either missing or awful.It sounds bad. I can't think of another game where the tutorial narration drew complaints from other people in my apartment but the voices in this game are honestly super annoying and also sound like every single one was done on the first take and never polished.It's boring. It's a "grand epic time scale" but that just boils down to watching time scroll by on fast forward, which is still super slow. I would say roughly a third of my playtime was just watching numbers scroll on the world map.It's opaque. The game wants you to Make Big Decisions, but you never know what is at stake, and you only have a tiny handful of choices AND you never find out what the results are for ages or maybe ever. It's simple. I don't mean in a stream lined "dive in and play" kind of way, I mean 3 classes and enemy AI that is nothing more than rushing straight at the nearest hero every time. It's just simplistic.I wanted to like this game. I promise I did. Nothing would have made me happier than for this to have been engaging and deep and interesting and complex. I would have loved to be wrong and I would have written a long review about how it was so much more than I was worried it would be. But the truth is it's not a good game.TLDR: it's bad in every way and not really worth free

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Deceptively simple yet complex, Massive Chalice will keep you interested for hours as you plan your nation, bloodlines, and strategies to fend off the Cadence. Interesting and challenging to balance bloodline stats and active party members to maximize the value of your people while staying viable in combat.Combat certainly takes good planning and strategy. Structure specific (Sagewright / Crucible) are the hardest by far. Enemy mobs also have a different spin on them in the ways they can defeat your heroes. Not only do you have to be concerned with your HP reaching zero, you also have to consider the effects of the Wrinker's aging attacks that can be devastating if you use a party of older heroes. The Twitchers also tend to appear at inopportune moments (usually from over a wall) to mix things up.As this is an early access review, game ran beautifully from start to finish with no complaints. Only actual issue I encountered was a mispelling (Critical was Criical or something) which I easily overlooked.

Early Access Review
								Supported through Kickstarter eons ago. Started playing some months ago when it had only 3 classes.It was fun even then. Played it through few times just to try different tactics. After the recent patch of hybrid classes it got even better. Squad turn-based tactics - with some random choices that may, or may not, screw you over - with ever changing panic over keeping a proper squad together as your keeps can't keep up with enough worthy heroes.Toss the crappy ones (slow, arithis, multiple negative stats) into guild to do research. Pick ones with positive effects - and later higher levels - for standards. And assemble best ones into frontline fighting squad. And cry when they get wiped. Random chance and mean AI makes each game a struggle at some point. Not enough heroes for full squad? Don't want to sacrifice your good heroes? Which area you're willing to lose.. Balancing for picking least annoying combat and best rewards.Compared to x-com or a like games this one has kept me interested longer. Still has some optimization issues considering system requirements for graphics, so saddly requires decent graphics card at least for now.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review: I don't see how this game can change a whole lot to make a vast improvement, which it really needs. If you've ever played X-COM, it's hard to play a dumbed down version of that. Massive Chalice has some really awesome concepts that work better on paper. You get to create several generations of blood and name that will go on for as long as you can keep them alive. They may have some weaknesses and strengths, and many of these can carry on for a couple hundred years. This can be alcoholism, higher HP, lower evasion, better aging, lower lifespan, better stealth, etc. The list goes on and I probably only got to play with a third of what's out there. The important thing is, once you find a strong bloodline, you stick with it and make it stronger. Sounds pretty cool, right?Well, unfortunately, there's not a whole lot else here. As time goes on, your birthing choices mean less and less and eventually you just want to get the game over with. The combat is challenging, but not complicated enough. You only have so much to work with, and it's not even 1/10th as intricate as X-COM. There's some fun concepts here like trying to plan your means of attack and stealthing in unseen on a group of 10 enemies. But it all starts to become fodder to a point. You get to saying "here we go again..." and finish it like you had the other 20 battles before it. So I just don't see how this game can be greatly improved on full release. I completed it with an emptiness to fill and hope the best for it. Unfortunately, it wasn't enough for me. I recommend getting this on a massive sale if you REALLY need to play this type of game.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								The games difficulty is intense, even somewhat ridiculous. The seemingly insurmountable odds stacked against (any non-hardcore) player seem challenging at first, but quickly become either annoyingly time-consuming (with save scumming) or off-puttingly random (with ironman mode) with its difficulty spikes. Making "easy" the only difficulty that fits a player that's not 100% committed always feels condescending. If the game was otherwise a complete gem, this could be forgiven. Unfortunately, it is not. The battles and environments are quirky and fun to look at for a while, but quickly wear out their appeal; it's obvious the art style is just a thin smokescreen for hiding sub-par, lazy graphics design.The game's lack of variety in difficulty, graphics and strategic content, lack of polish and the baffling decision to let people to create shoddy and very unfunny custom content in the form of Bloodlines (character descriptions/battle dialogue) just leaves an impression that the game's creators don't really want to make the effort to produce high-quality content. The Bloodlines, rife with bad jokes and knockoff GoT quotes, are a testament to the game's shortcomings; the developers have made no effort (yet) to polish the player-created content, but also did not include an option to disable said amateur garbage. It's like a comic book that's sold as the work of a professional comics studio but all the pages are mostly colored in by unpaid and inept first graders. At it's current stage, MASSIVE CHALICE seems to be a brilliant concept that's gotten trashed by a lazy, unrefined design process.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game seemed like a game I was going to love. I am a huge fan of tactical, turn-based combat games. XCom is one of my favorite games. However, this game lacks a lot of contents I'd expect from a game like this:TACTICAL COMBAT:It's just plain boring. Your heros gain skills as they level, but the combat itself is lacking. By the time I reached my third invasion by the Cadence (enemy plant race), I was just tired of it. Each combat scenerio is the same and very repeatative, and you lack a variety of classes and specializations to keep it interesting.BLOODLINE/BIRTHING:This is probably the only interest thing about this game. You assign a regent to a territory and marry them off to someone. Based on their fertility and skills, they'll give birth to a lot of children that pick up some of their traits. You have to be careful not to pair up two people with horrible traits, or you risk a good deal of horrible warriors being birthed.CUSTOMIZATION:Practically NONE. What I love about XCom is the fact you get to customize each of your soldiers. You choose their hair, face, voice, what they wear and even give them first, last and nicknames. Massive Chalice only allows you to change your hero's armor and weapon... and that's even limited. For me--customizing my characters is not only extremely entertaining, but it emotionally invests me in those characters and when they die in battle... I actually care.KINGDOM BUILDING:Yep. Boring. I imagined having an entire kingdom to build things like blacksmiths, guilds, research towers, etc. Nope. You  build keeps to fill a territory and assign a regent, and then you just wait around to birth children to fill your army once they reach the age of 15. You can also research something, but you can only research one thing at  time. And constructing buildings, for some reason, is considered research. Instead of having several different areas to work on multiple projects (building, researching, crafting) you literally can only do ONE thing at a time. And you wait. And wait. AND WAIT some more for something interesting to happen.OVERALL:Yes. It's an Early Access Game, but based on what's in the game right now... there's not much going to change. The core mechanics are there, and they're lacking. If you enjoy tactical, turn-based combat games... buy XCom: Enemy Unknown. You can get the main game and all expansions for the same price as this game. Plus--XCom is a top-notched game with a ton of content, customization, intenst tactical combat and a great storyline.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												After playing a couple hours on normal mode with the tutorial I can say I really enjoy this game. There is a lot to learn and I'm sure I've already screwed on something that'll bite me later. I love the system for creating heirs, it's actually pretty easy to learn, but there's so much to pay attention to I don't get bored with it. The heroes are important and I grew attached to a few, but their lives are so fleeting and there are so many that I wasn't too devestated when they died of old age or on the battlefield. The heir system reminds me of rogue legacy a lot, and the combat is quick and fun. I still haven't experienced many classes beyond the beginning set I had, but they do play differently and you can really feel that when your drunk team member hits for two damage and the hunter has to save their butt again. I mean really, girl, can't you sober up in the face of danger? I've barely scratched the surface of this game, and I look forward to getting deeper into the story and playing again when I'm not so clueless. I'm sure people who are veterans at this style of game will pick it up easily, and new players should have no trouble learning with the tutorial.The art style isn't too detailed, nor is the game processor heavy. The main screen looks like a board game, and the game feels like that at times, with you playing against the bad guys. I feel like the style works well with the fact that while the heroes aren't nameless, they are many, and frequently changing. Characters age with time and this affects their abilities in and out of battle. Pros:Tutorial will get anyone up to speed quicklyEarly battles are quick and funHeir system is fun and complex, easy to learn but hard to masterRuns just fine on my 7 year old laptop fast-forwarding time makes it easier to get stuff doneCons: It's not the shiniest game ever? If you're looking for movie realistic or fancy cutscenes this is not the game for you.There's no multiplayer though I don't miss it.I felt a little lost about which land to save since the benefits were only partially explained.

												I was going to give MASSIVE CHALICE a pass.Give it a 'ha-ha, you got me again Double Fine, when will I ever learn' and just carry on with my life.That is until I saw it on my friend's wishlist. Friends don't let friends play MASSIVE CHALICE. It's not addicting, heh, it's anything but addicting. The most it will get out of you is 10h of dredging through a blandness swamp. In the latter half of the campaign they really start not giving a f**k and just inject steroids in the enemies you've already been tired of for hours and stop introducing anything remotely new.Turn-based battles, Noble houses that have their own character class and inherited pros and cons,Equipment research,Fighting an ever-rising tide of evil forces,these are just some of the things you thought were going to make a great game, before you saw them realized this blandly and with as less effort as possible. Funny enough the one redeeming quality of the game, its unique visual aesthetic, also can be attributed to the development team just deciding textures or high-poly meshes just don't fit their busy schedule of not making a good game.This one goes to you, Pufe, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I backed this game because the concept of XCOM meets breeding simulator sounded interesting.  It is!  And it's pretty fun too!  Enemy types are inventive in that it's not just straight damage dealers - you have enemies that subtract XP or age your heroes on hit.  There's the aspect of when do you retire heroes for breeding or research versus keeping them in the fight.  It's a mildly stressful balancing act but that's part of the charm.  I beat the game in 12 hours (with one reset in the very early game because I thought I messed up) on the normal difficulty.  It's entertaining, charming and a little different with mechanics that are as straightforward as any game I've ever seen.  It seems to go for $20 normally and I'd say it's worthwhile at that price, but if it goes on sale, snap it up!

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Shallow, and none of the individual parts are done especially well. Every single mission is "wipe out the enemy". The classes are dull and unimaginative. The "world/dynasty" building layer is uninteresting.Basically, DF bit off more than they could chew and ditched support for the game when it was clear no one else was buying into it - so I'm glad I held off and picked this up when it was 80% off. It's a shame, because the concept is a really interesting one - but DF of late appear to be going the "grab money, make something, doesn't matter if it's actually any good because it's not our money and we can't be held accountable unlike traditional publishing methods" route.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												This game has some really good parts but could use some more polish. The paucity of classes reduces the fun factor significantly. Also, the alchemist archers are fairly OP. I found the alchemists tended to run out of ammo too fast and the close up guys had too much trouble with exploding enemies to be very good most of the time, though their stun is nice once in awhile.Combat gets repetetive pretty quick. There aren't really enough enemy types to keep it fresh. Simply adding more HP midgame does not make it more fun.The tuitorial leaves lots of stuff out, like items and like "how to prevent land from falling away into the acid." I never feel like I get enough time with my heroes. I really like the ideas but the execution leaves a lot to be desired.I got this in a bundle, I did actually specifically boost my pledge just to get this because I'd had my eye on it for awhile. I am glad I got it that way. It's been fun enough that I can't in good conscience give it a thumbs down, but unless this recieves some significant updates I would not spend more than $8-10 on this.

Early Access Review
								MASSIVE CHALICE plays like a "diet" version of the new XCOM games, with all the trimmed fat replaced with a compelling Crusader Kings 2-esque bloodline metagame. It's still only Early Access, but it's already playable from start to finish, and absolutely sublime.Worth noting: the game's full release is slated for early next year, and development is fully funded to that point, so put aside any issues you may have with Double Fine. If you like tactics games, you've got no reason not to grab this right now!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												The schtick of the game is that you manage a fantasy realm for 300 years in a prolonged seige from an otherworldly badguy.  You have a few bloodlines of heroes, and the top-level gameplay sees you assigning them to a few different roles.  They can be part of your vanguard (strike team used in tactical levels), you put them in baby farms keeps to produce more heroes (cause the game goes for something like ten generations), they can take on the white to become a sage (speeding your research times), and your most awesome heroes can become standards in the training crucibles (boosting all heroes kingdom-wide).Meanwhile, the badguy threat the "Cadence" attacks your lands (in which you build keeps, crucibles, and sagewright guilds).  You send in your vanguard and play a blessedly short tactical exercise to take them down.  There are always more attacks than you can address, though, and the Cadence's corruption seeps into your lands, eventually destroying them.  So you're constantly triaging your threats, knowing that you won't be able to keep everything, but holding out for retaining enough to make it to the endgame.The endgame, by the way, is when the titular Massive Chalice fills up and can destroy all the Cadence forever.  That takes 300 years.  But you're immortal thanks to the power of the Chalice, so you can manage things until the endgame… assuming you can hold everything together until then.The Good:Dividing your resources (ie heroes) between vanguard, breeders, sages, and standards is surprisingly difficult, challenging, and consequential, and continues to be so throughout the game.  Your heroes have various traits, both genetic and acquired via training, and they pass these down to their kids and their trainees (and sometimes their comrades-in-arms).  There is a whole lot of fun fiddling and arranging what traits you want your baby farms keeps to produce.  Or who you're willing to put into the sages instead.  Or who's going to fight for you, or who's going to train the kingdom's heroes.   This is, from a game design standpoint, a real victory.  It is some seriously elegant, downright exquisite, design.  So the strategic level of the game gets an A+.The character classes are amusingly different from your standard fantasy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  You have caberjacks, whose weapons are giant, iron-shod logs.  You have alchemists, who sling explosive potions.  Lastly you have hunters, who can stealth and shoot things with their crossbows.  You can shunt these into the tank/dps/aoe structures you're used to, but you don't have to.You also get hybrid classes (when a mommy caberjack and a daddy hunter love each other very very much…) which make for interesting combinations.  Trickshots shoot arrows tipped with explosive potions.  Shadowjacks can stealth and then leap out of the shadows with their massive cabers.  And so on.  As you can see, as you start figuring out hybrid classes, things get weirder, not more predictable, and it's lots of fun to explore those new options.And there are relic weapons that get passed down from generation to generation, leveling up as they get used, and becoming incredible items of power.  Nothing says dynasty of super-powered warriors like a crossbow that's been passed down within the noble house for 200 years.  Towards the end of my playthrough, which youngster got bequeathed a relic more-or-less determined who was going to be in the vanguard.  There's a lot of thematic power in that decision, where you're figuring if this 13-year-old lordling shows enough promise to be given the mighty Monarch crossbow.  I really got into it!While there are a lot of Game of Thrones elements in there, it's also notable what things are _not_ carried over from the most popular fantasy property of the day.  Namely, you have all these noble houses in your kingdom, but they do not conspire or scheme or complain to you.  They don't have petty rivalries, they do not undermine the realm with their ambitions.  This would be a natural development to pursue, but ultimately it would detract from gameplay.  Your job isn't to convince the realm to fight against the White Walkers Cadence, it's to manage that fight.  Good on the designers for not falling down that rabbit hole.Also the game is pleasantly gender-neutral in regards to you, the sovereign, even though it sticks pretty strongly to the gender binary for your baby farms regents.  I'll take my victories where I can get them on this front!The Not-So-Good:The game suffers from the common trope of the Big Final Battle being unlike any other battle you've fought before, so all of the expectations and strategies that you've honed over the course of the game are just slightly off-base.  (Mild spoilers; skip to next paragraph to avoid…) Instead of using your team of five heroes sweeping an area for the 15-20 badguys hiding on a map, you set your team of five heroes to defending a single target against wave after wave of badguys who teleport in every few turns.  Worse, there is zero indication if you have four waves to go, or one, or fifteen.  Given that part of the game is resource management, withholding this information does not do the endgame scenario any favors.More mundanely, except for that last one, the battles all have the same objective: kill all the badguys.  Every once in a while, the game mixes things up and has the badguys attacking a keep and you have to defend the regent of the keep… by killing all the badguys.  I often complain that the objectives of tactical games miss a lot of potential, and this game unfortunately falls squarely into the same trap.The UI does a good job presenting a torrent of information that you need to manage, but there are some unfortunate lapses.  The worst is the fact that, while every character has a Strength, Agility, and Intelligence stat, nowhere does it tell you what those stats actually do—and they don't operate in traditional "Agility to hit, Strength for damage" ways.  Luckily a quick internet search will answer these questions, but still: not something I should have to do to understand the game.  More puzzling, this is a known problem and could be addressed in a very simple patch, but it hasn't been.Overall:This is a slick, powerful, engaging game, and I'm holding off starting another playthrough because I've got stuff to do.  I know if I start another, it will consume all my time like the last round.  I still haven't explored the Alchemists hardly at all, and feel like I missed some clever uses for caberjacks.  I'm eager to try it again, but I'm not sure if I want to play at Normal difficulty like last time or submit myself to the harrowing of a harder difficulty level.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												hell yeah. if arranged marriages intrigues you. get this game. no really, it was the most fun thing about this game from my pov. starting a family with a weak whiny cadence burger, into a full blown warrior tribe of awesomeness. the game play is also fun too, see x-com, but with a medieval twist, also you actually hit your shots, how amazing!. theres research and random events to keep you busy in between attacks. also your heroes will constantly die, but there's homegrown  fresh blood to replace them. note, you cannot name characters and houses if that's a big thing to you,(it reallly shouldn't be you whiny spitbag)it doesn't affect me at all. i found myself growing close to some of my houses, who had grown to formidable strength. individuals do sometimes get lost in the shuffle, but the true heroes that are called upon every time there's an attack are sorely missed upon their death. and sometimes they pass down their weapon to a family member, which is cool. in my current run i'm at year 250ish and i dont really feel like finishing,i most likely will, but i'd rather restart, i feel the strong parts of the game are the begginning up to the midlate. its starting to get stale( i feel there's no more strategy to the research part, i'm just randomly assigning research at this point, maybe a higher difficulty is in order?, and the game overall is getting kinda grindish(repetitive)(my whole kingdom was basically decked out by year 180 probably), but starting over should remove that feeling. buy this game you won't be disappointed. but you should wait for a sale, i got it for 8 bucks. i would've been pleased even if i paid 20, but i know others people won't be.

												The top rated reviews had me a little wary on this title, but since they were all Early Access complaints, and the game previewed positively, I decided to give it a shot. It's a blast! It's a fantasy cousin to XCom, with neat visuals, warm character voices, and all of the fun feels you'd expect from a production of DoubleFine. Games last from 10-20 hours, and it starts very easy, and quickly becomes highly challenging.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												I played this off and on through beta, but now that it is at full release with balance, I am really enjoying it! They have done a great job with a tactical turn based game. The different classes now have great feel and I use them all. It used to be that only the long range characters were worth using, but now I love my melee caberjack's! They have done a good job with the bloodlines and aging features, and it is everything I actually was looking for when I Kickstarted it. It feels polished and pretty well balanced. Well done Doublefine.Pros: Interesting classes and hybrid classes. Clean visuals and fairly easy UI system. Good bloodlines system, and good approach with upgrades in general. Cons: Locations not super diverse, I wish we could choose different colors for keeps etc.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Like XCOM, this is a game about fog-of-war-focused tactical combat with a greater strategy layer above it, best played in Ironman Mode. XCOM is better, but this game is still worth experiencing.Rather than being about cover management, the tactical combat part is about trying to kill enemies before they ever get a chance to attack you, where the enemies are dumb as bricks. So, sometimes entertaining, and sometimes rather unimpressive, and on the whole a bit less great.The strategy layer is a closer match though; it's got the same level of researchyness, with the additional hero breeding mechanic. I think the tactical combat's balance kind of wears down on the strategy layer though: there are many elements that make it easier to focus on upgrading and breeding only one class, but the tactical rewards for diversifying do not really make overcoming those elements worthwhile.Oh, and the voices in this game are rather unimpressive. Every once in a long while during a battle, one or both of the chalice-people will say something useless from their rather small set of things they can say. My favorites being "Good riddance!" when an ally dies (if an enemy was killed in the crossfire), and "Ha! Following my advice paid off!" (or something like that) when nobody has said anything. There are individual Red Alert 2 units that have more lines than this game. Almost.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												(Full disclosure: I backed this game on Kickstarter but didn't play it until the release.)After my wife complained about the game being unplayably difficult, even on the easiest difficulty, I decided it was time to give Massive Chalice a try.I played about half way through a full game on the normal difficulty, with tutorials on and the game difficulty doesn't seem balanced to me. Some battles are really easy then you'll have one that's nearly impossible. Because battles are spaced so far apart it's also difficult to build any kind of team because two fights from now everyone on the current team is dead of old age. I also suspect there are some underlying game mechanics that aren't being exposed for regent marriages. By the time I finished playing I had four different keeps and figure I must have intermarried between them or something because despite having 1-2 dozen heros available of both sexes, only one or two people would show up as elligible for a regent to marry. I coudn't figure out an actual reason why this is happening so the only thing I can figure is that there's some unexposed game rule about someone marrying their cousin. =)All in all it feels like a game that could have used a bit more work. I'm fine with bad things happening in a game like XCOM, because it's usually something I did that caused it, this game is frustrating because it feels like I did everything "right" yet still ended up losing in the end.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												20 minutes in and I'm already giving up.  Framerate was awful... maybe 15 fps on a new Mac.  Tutorial said I could hit the [End] key to perform an action but this is a Mac and it does not have an [End] key; their QA team should have caught that.  I tried dialing back the video settings to get better fps but even at the lowest settings the framerate was still lame.  So I clicked [Reset] to restore the defaults but when I clicked [Apply] nothing happened; I had to restart the game again to apply the settings.  They seem to have implemented their own proprietary keyboard driver which basically ignores my OS settings where I just tap the touchpad to perform a click... with this game I actually have to depress the trackpad hard to do a basic left click.  Maybe this game is good but after so many annoying and preventable issues so early on, I'm cutting my losses and moving on.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												I like Double Fine, no, love is more accurate, but this is a serious misstep. Gameplay: This is a pared down version of the latest XCom games that ramps up the frustrating parts right over the garden wall. That may seem facetious, but it even observes the same adherence to the passage of time, the meticulous planning of building and research, and the bitter mocking when a hero dies. They haven't included injuries sustained during combat, deciding instead to build those directly into a heroes core statistics by the usage of "traits" and "flaws". Your heroes do feel a bit more powerful as you can mow down twice as many enemies in one battle as you ever could in XCom and the monsters do provide a nice palette of obstacles to overcome. Of course, your heroes only live about sixty or so years which goes by surprisingly quick, so it is difficult to form much attachment. I suppose one is supposed to develop a fondness for a clan of heroes that you breed over generations, but it seems rather pointless when you're maintaining the houses much in the same way one takes care of an ant farm. Normally, I would not directly fault a game for copying another game's mechanics, but DoubleFine is a studio I look to when I want good design, gameplay, and solid writing. Which leads me to my next point:Story: The writing is weak. There's a diad of narrators that fall so predictably into bad cliches and poor acting that I simply had to turn the sound off; no hint or narrative point could be worth that. Despite the game allowing you to choose a "Silly" and a "Serious" mode as far as randomly generated names go, I lost all love and respect for the heroes I was grooming when their nicknames arose as "Fishfingers". The game flits between wanting to be a comedy and wanting to be a grim war and mortality simulator so nervously that I can't commit myself to any emotion other than anger when I play it.Sound: Aside from what I've already mentioned there is nothing special here, the sound is just passable and you will get tired of the soundtrack before your first playthrough is up.I was very much looking forward to this game and was elated to see it pop up on sale, I will have to give DoubleFine a second look before I plunge into anything of theirs again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												The interesting part about this game is that you are suppose to manage bloodlines, breed desirable traits and weed out bad traits. The problem with the game is that you never get the feeling that a blood line is distinctive, like for example most heros from this blood line has high strength but are sickly and prone to die early.The reason is because, within a few generations the bloodline's trait might change wildly into something completely different from the start. Although this means that it is easy to get rid of bad traits, it means that those bad traits keep coming back. It also means that good traits does not stick and you are left hoping that RNG favours you and generate children who have the good traits but not the bad ones. Every generation you must play this RNG again and sooner or later you are going to lose and drop back to square one.What they should have done is instead of having binary on/off states for the traits, the traits should be a gradient. For example the quick study and slow learner traits should be combines into a single trait that give +/- exp modifier. Every children will inherit a slightly different modifier. Small changes should be more common than large changes so that you cannot breed good learning within a few generations. At the sametime you can't lose it easily in a single generation if the RNG goes against you.The game fails at its most unique aspect, which is a shame because with some tweaks it could have worked much better.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
The game: Massive Chalice is an event driven quasi turn based tactical battle game (see description below ^.^) with resource management in form of generation spanning unit spawning, time and kingdom management (wow!) that features a “massive chalice” (no spoilers here – you will find out soon enough) and also a mysterious enemy force called the “cadence” :	The tactical battle part of the game is straight forward: different unit and enemy types, units progress via experience points (xp) and earn different skills. Your basic Seek & Destroy gameplay with developing units.	BUT! Your units (heroes from different families) can die of old age, you can let them get married to transfer parts of their characteristics to daughters and sons [thus creating new units (and new types of units) or transfer specialized skills and traits (also the bad ones) to your offspring]. Or you can let them do research to use the knowledge they gained in all those years fighting the enemy. So not so basic after all! 	Each time an event occurs, e.g. birth, death, attack, research, building – That is basically a turn in the turn-based tactical part of the game, but it may be 2 years or 20 years in between – you can react to said event with new building orders, arranging marriage for two of your hero_ines or change the direction of your research.What happens during the game is this: You start your kingdom with different families. Each family is providing the kingdom with fighters which in turn can create offspring. The different heroes at your disposal come with a wide variety of bonus skills and also with a bit of bad genes / upbringing. Some are anxious and easily panicked, others like to see the bottom of a wine bottle a little too often and similar traits that definitely won´t help in a fight. Some are courageous, noble, fast, and strong. So there is some help after all! You have to choose what role each hero is going to play, for the future of the kingdom. It can be a fighting role, a researching scribe, a healthy marriage with another member of your growing royal family (or should I say clan?). Or you may be unlucky and loose one of yours to a disease or some other unhealthy random event.When it comes to battles with the enemy you get a randomly generated battlefield. In the confinements of those areas, which differ in size and setup, you have to defeat the enemy utilizing your unit’s skills and your own tactical prowess. Look and feel and sound: The game has a clunky looking graphics style, which fits perfectly. The game is not about looks, it is about a fully voiced Chalice that sort of gives the game its name. It is about silly! family names and lot of (failed?) attempts at saving your kingdom from the enemy, from plagues, from old age and from general uselessness. Captains Orders: The game is an absolute blast to play! I totally enjoyed the easy to pickup fighting parts and I liked the kingdom planning even more. It is not an in-depth tactical monstrosity like for example x-com, don´t let the similar mechanics in battle fool you. It is a game for some short and fun tactical sessions. You can easily pick up your kingdom in the middle of its pride after having had a few days off, playing something else. Go grab it – if you like tactical battles mixed with kingdom management in an atmospheric game that has a charm of its own! And did i mention silly! random names?Verdict: Treasure! Will be massively featured on Land Ho! with Captn3mo[www.twitch.tv]

number of helpful: 48 of 98 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Do you like X-Com: Enemy Unknown?Do you like games that are overflowing with personality?Do you like games where you can lose spectacularly and have a blast while doing it?In Massive Chalice, your adventurers are your kings and queens, your scholars, and they train the next generation to keep fighting.  And your adventurers will die.  Whether it is heroically in battle or just from old age, your squad of heroes will pass on their relics and traits to the next generation.It's Rogue mixed with X-Com and it is freaking awesome.During my first playthrough, I was so excited to build my keeps, select the best personality traits and try to groom the most ideal bloodlines.  I built a grand cathedral for study, and put my top minds to work researching the latest and greatest technology.And then I found that I had nobody left to go out and battle!  And then my perfect matches had marital problems!  I lost a baby and the mother during childbirth!  Everything had been going so well!  My kingdom was thriving and then RUIN!  I had rulers on thrones with no spouse to get the next generation going.  I had an army of 67 year old grenadiers who tripped and broke their hips before they even got to the enemy.  GET BACK UP AND GET IN THERE YOU GERIATRIC ADVENTURERS!!!!They died spectacularly and my kingdom was overrun.But holy crap was it fun.  I've never lost so overwhelmingly and yet had so much fun doing so.  The two voices that make up the Massive Chalice are hilarious and their personality is as overflowing as the water in the chalice.  This game is fantastic.  The graphics suit the gameplay and the flavour of the game spectacularly and enhance the experience.Buy this game.Play this game.Lose to this game several times before you figure out how to make babies (it shouldn't be that hard, right?).Then, once you're done losing a few times, go out there and defeat the corruption in the most spectacularly hilarious ways.10/10

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Massive Chalice (beta) is an interesting new spin on turn-based strategies. There are several levels of strategy you need to think about when playing.You only control a small squad of 5 heroes when in combat, which means you need to use terrain and other tactics in order to survive. The death of a single hero in combat affects other areas of the game.Everything surrounds a single goal: protect the massive talking (multi-personality I might add) chalice at the center of the map. The chalice is surrounded by regions which in turn are surrounded, from all directions, by the enemy which creeps ever closer. The big talky chalice promises it has a way to defeat the enemy but says "It takes time. A lot of time", so we have to defend it until then.Placing keeps and guilds in each region takes time - I'm talking years. Fortunately the years move quite quickly. Unfortunately, the lives of your heroes span those years in real time, which means they get old and they eventually die of old age (unless killed in battle).In order to maintain a line of heroes you have the option to make them regents (or regent partners). This stops the heroes from entering the battlefield and instead focus of making the next generation of heroes. You now need to find the right combination of heroes to produce offspring with attributes that can defeat the enemy more efficiently.Overall I found the game to be semi-light hearted, enjoyable, and also a challenge. You're often attacked on multiple fronts which means you have to pick your battles. The character models could do with a little bit of 'prettifyling' I suppose, but hey, you're not pairing them together for their looks now are you? :)If you're looking for a new turn-based challenge, have a look!

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is not a carbon copy of XCOM, it's more like inspired by XCOM, as well as much more difficult. The main thing this game has in common with XCOM is the combat mechanics and permadeath and these are not bad game mechanics so I believe it's acceptable. Every choice matters and your soldiers (named Heroes) WILL die and you will have to accept this. I love this game but not because of its combat, (which is very light strategy and needs some fine tuning to be satisfactory) but because of everything outside of combat. You rule a kingdom and control when time starts and stops. Time means everything in this game, as well as the age, experience, fertility, and traits of your heroes. Even some enemy designs revolve around these subjects, a type of enemy can cause you to lose experience, or make you older by 5 to 10 years, or even make you sterile. Your people WILL die on the battle field. Accept it. The artstyle is fantastic and the gameplay outside of combat is very intriguing and interesting. Now for the enemy types, the only thing I have a problem with is how powerful the enemies are. I don't mind a challenge but I believe some tweaks would improve their combat mechanics, such as for example, the Lapses who when hit a hero they drain experience, the amount of experience should dialed down. Also the variability of hit success can be infuriating at times, (f.e. 87% chance to land a successful hit and misses can be very  frustrating.) This game is a work in progress for sure, however despite it's flaws it is well worth the price and extremely fun, satisfying, and very challenging. 9.5/10! In case you don't think this review is helpful because I may be confusing in how I feel about this game, it's worth the money if you enjoy strategy games like XCOM. If you don't enjoy those types of games then you won't enjoy this one. Simple as that. For thirty bucks though this is worth it.
