number of helpful: 28 of 58 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off, this is in early access, and I backed the Kickstarter at the time so take that for what it's worth.Massive Chalice is a turn-based tactical game in the same vein as, but on a smaller scale than, X-Com.  Where it differs is in the meta-game; rather than building a base and managing resources, you're managing the family trees of your squad.  You do still research equipment and choose buildings for the different regions in the kingdom, but it's a more limited set of choices than you may be used to.  The overall aim of the game is to survive as a kingdom under threat, until the titular Massive Chalice is able to purge the threat from your lands forever.The heroes that make up your squad (up to 5 at a time) are born, they age, gain experience and abilities, and die.  They will die a lot, and saving and reloading when a mission goes poorly won't save them.  The timeline that you are trying to survive through means that even if everything goes according to plan, your heroes will still eventually succumb to old age.  The trick is to ensure you have enough new heroes being born (with beneficial heriditary traits) to replace them.On a functional level, the game looks and sounds beautiful.  The art design is outstanding, and I wouldn't be surprised to see it win some awards at the end of the year.  It is still in Beta, but I've not experienced any game-breaking bugs.I've followed the development of the game throughout the process, from concept art to playing it on Steam, thanks to DoubleFine's excellent TeamStreams.  I understand why certain decisions have been made, and while there are some tweaks I'd like to see to the balancing, overall the game is challenging, fun, pretty, and a triumph for open game development that I hope more developers learn from in the future.  :D

number of helpful: 28 of 58 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								THIS IS A BETA REVIEW.I've played about 2 hours of the game (30 years of the 300 year timeline). So far, I like the game, and I see potential for continued improvement before the final release.The game does play like a fantasy X-COM in a lot of ways, but I was also reminded of the random good and bad traits from Rogue Legacy. These affect your strategic choices because many can be transmitted genetically (so be careful who you choose to found bloodlines) or socially (so be careful who you appoint as trainers). I also feel losing a valuable soldier hurts less in Massive Chalice than in X-COM, because all your soldiers are going to age and die anyway. It's a neat twist.WHAT I LIKE:- the graphics are charming; I like the style- the choices on the strategic planning map are challenging and I feel there are probably multiple good (no "best") choicesWHAT I'D LIKE TO SEE CHANGED:- unit variety I'd like more than three classes, and some way to "blend" abilities of different classes (e.g., one parent's an alchemist and the other's a hunter, so the kids they raise are a little bit of each)- silly catchphrases make me roll my eyes a bit; maybe the "serious mode vs. silly mode" setting (I forget what it's actually called) isn't implemented yet?- eventually, I'd like to see an option to let the timeline extend beyond 300 yearsAnyway, I've enjoyed what I've played of Massive Chalice so far, and will be on the look out for future updates.

number of helpful: 28 of 58 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game takes two of my favorite games Crusader Kings II and XCOM and mashes them together in a way that fixes some of the glaring flaws in XCOMs design.This game takes place over Hundreds of years and you are managing a nation and stable of heroes across multiple generations. Through out the game you will build keeps to further bloodlines, crucibles for training and Sagewrights guild for research. You will also engage in some genetic engineering through selective pairing to get the best possible heroes. The heroes you pair do a few things. 1. They have a chance to pass along some of their traits (positive and negative) to their kids. 2. They pass along some of their XP. This alone fixes the massive flaw in XCOM, by the midgame of XCOM any new recruit you get is useless to you. Now your new recruits are able to scale in power as the game progresses. The other big flaw involves "losing" a battle. While there is no "ironman" mode that I can see, I play with it self imposed on myself. In XCOM ironman mode, a team wipe is essentially a loss state. You likely have no team of soldiers that can adequately replace a team that fought something tough enough to get wiped by. In MC, a team wipe hurts, you spread more "corruption" (Panic) and obviously you lost your heroes, BUT it is not a game over scenario as you have a team to fight with comeing through the ranks (at least you should) infact, losing members of your team can result in the creation of a "Relic", a weapon that it bound to the bloodline of the hero, can critical strike, and grows stronger as you use it. The game is a blast to manage if you love XCOM and CKII. It is still unfinished at this time, the only feature that I can tell is missing is hybrid classes, but the game plays great without it right now. If there was one thing I would add to this game it would be an active/reactive combat system like Gladius, but that is just me being wishful for Gladius II...The actual tactical battles are cleverly done with some cool maps and the different types of enemies add some good depth to the combat, certain enemies need to be approached the right way or they can really cause problems at different points in the game. Lapses in the late game are nasty, wrinklers in the mid game, Bulwarks in the early game. They all attack very differently (especially in the case of Lapses and Wrinklers) and in ways that are thematically appropriate (messing with time) and not simply a case of one just hitting harder. The one knock I do have is once the 5-6 different enemies are rolled out it kinda stops, eventually they all become "advanced" versions of the same thing, no reskins, no different mechanics. That is an area for improvement as the game moves to launch.There is no difficulty setting I can see, but the games difficulty is more than adequate, however as you get a bit more familiar with the items you can equip, you can use the imformation about the types of enemies you are facing to give your guys a leg up. In future playthroughs I am going to try and not look at that information before battles as the game got a lot easier once I started really looking at the types of enemies I would face pre-battle.One successful playthrough (3rd try) took me about 25 hours and it already has great replay value in the randomness of it's design. As it sits right now it is worth the price of admission and this game will only improve as it gets closer to launch. The short version is that this game took XCOM and made it better in almost every way, even in it's presently unfinished state.

number of helpful: 26 of 54 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Recommended because I want this game to be better :/Ok so this game isn't finished, and to be considered finished it needs a lot of work. game play is like final fantasy tacticsonly 3 classes, Cabberjack (melee) hunter(ranged)alchemist (hybrid, glass cannons)At first glance I feel like there should be more classes, like maybe 2 more, a healer and a assassin. However if you play long enough you find that in place of a generic "healer class" any one can be a healer, but it's a little hard to figure out.It's little things like this that make the game interesting, but it runs into problems. For instance to be a healer you have to research this health potion, that you can equip on anyone. (you only get 1 health potion per character if they have it equipped, and it heals for 10 hp). But you are limited to only one item per character, this wouldn't be a problem if your characters could hit anything for their lives. So you have to get the item that makes their accuracy higher (by 15%) even with this I found my guys still missing point blank shots, or missing against inanimate objects. More often than not I had scenarios where my guys didn't hit a single thing, and everyone just died. I mean come on! their warriors, dedicating their lives to protect a kingdom and they couldn't hit the broad side of a barn.Also the mechanics of their hit rates seemed all over the place, Sometimes I found  at the furthest distance you can be from an enemy you get a better hit percentage, but sometimes that idea went right out the window. Also there is no indicator of how far a move can go before you move your character. leaving me with guys one space shy of being able to hit something a lot of the time. (attack ranges of at least your characters needs to be displayed) many games like final fantasy tactics, or Disgea execute this much better. Some voice acting issuessome of the banter between your 2 chalice deities or w/e seems like it was cut short, and some cut scenes show a glowing light when ever they talk, but they stop talking and the light keeps flickering, and it feels like you missed the end of a conversation half the time. illusion of freedomyou are given a lot of choices to upgrade your kingdom, but I found myself not making it past the 4th or 5th battles If I didn't stick to a precise set of upgrades. Enemies get a lot harder each time you have a battle. There is a nice pull and push in fighting back oncoming enemies. You are attacked by 2 groups, one you can kill, the other takes 1/3 of the tile. So you have an important decision on what you need to defend. However some tiles ie. the most outer ones (going to be attacked 1st every time) have perks to them. like makes research faster, or lvls up your guys faster. having them only on the outer edge of the map seems stupid. there should be a perk per tile. You're going to loose tiles no matter what and it feels like a whole one step forward 2 steps back process.Leveling up your heroes:This is a hard mechanic to get your 1st play through, and you won't rly know how to do it efficiently until like your 2nd-4th play through.You heroes die of old age pretty fast, so instead of lvling them up you really need to pass down (items/relics) that get better with every generation. Also parents pass down traits, some good some bad. So don't get attached to anyone, get attached to bloodlines. This is a cool mechanic too, buuuuuuuuuut to do this you need higher lvl heroes to become rulers of their keeps (bloodline homes) and it's rly hard to start a bloodline when all you ever have are clumsy dorks who usually have crappy stats to begin with because they are lvl 1, and you can't really get anyone better because they have to die off, and by that time you may or may not have already lost the game. level design:some levels have really cool mechanics, like moving obstetrical that can be pushed or destroyed by enemies and this lets you block off areas, obstruct enemy vision ,and is a pretty cool mechanic, buuuuuuuuuuuuuut( sigh) it's only in 2 levels. The one with the egg shaped blocks that can move around, and the other level with geysers. visuals:AWESOME! Doublefine is great at making games with their own character, and this game is no exception. I just wish the game was not so frustratingly, and sometimes, impossibly difficult. This game has a long way to go if it's going to be good, and I want it to be good, that's why I got it.To support them, there was a kick starter and stuff, but they still need a help.     :(

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Having completed my first game, I would liken Massive Chalice as a XCOM light in a fantasy setting, with a twist; bloodlines. Light because it doesn't have the depth and content of XCOM. There is little explanation on what Cadence really is, and there are only 2 types of missions; defend the keep and defend the territory, aside from the final mission. That said, the game is also about half the price of XCOM.The concept of bloodlines is interesting but unfortunately, the drawback is that your heroes die so fast from aging, you will not develop any attachment to them, unlike XCOM. You will have to plan carefully on what to do with your heroes, making sure that you have a sufficient fighting force and at the same time, enough set aside to research and continue the next generation. In my opinion, while the game is fun, it needs more polish, balancing and CONTENT. I wouldn't mind paying more if the game has more content. As it stands, I would rate it a 7/10.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've lost 40 hours to this game in the early stages of beta, and I'm still ready for more. The game is great as it is, but will only become more balanced, polished and rewarding in the run up to the spring 2015 release. I kickstarted this game, and the team have been really responsive, streaming their development progress every couple of weeks the whole time, and it's been fun to be a part of, so if the idea of helping fine tune a game's mechanics sounds cool to you, I'd definitely consider Early Access. So far they've been responding really well to everyone's feedback with several significant balance tweaks in the short 3 weeks since the backer beta began.Even if you just want to play the game, there's a fine XCOM style strategy already working here with a generational twist, and if that sounds like your thing, I can totally recommend picking it up either now or once it's totally done in the spring if you'd rather play something completely done - but you can play it start to finish right now and have a great time.Add in super distinctive art direction and a wonderful soundtrack, as well as some very Double-Finey touches to the world building and writing, and this is one of my favourite games of the year, which is quite an achievement for something that's still got a few months of development left to go!

								Train your heroes, guide them in battle and then make sure that enough of them get married and have children that you can repeat the process.This game is all about pitting the needs of the realm's future against the need to guard the realm from present danger and I loved playing through it even in its current early access state.The turn based combat is reminiscent of XCOM or Shadowrun returns but instead of managing cover you need to manage line of sight, enemies that cannot see you cannot shoot you. content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has me spending way too much time than what I should be (in a good way). Once I start playing I have difficulty turning it off as there is always "one-more event" that I begin counting down to and the battles are engaging and well designed.I really enjoy the "recruitment" process of marrying off your heroes and having them found dynasties to continue producing heirs and playable heroes. It's a great twist on how heroes are usually recruited, especially with the ability to breed for particular traits.It's great how much the game is actually affected by this mechanic, as you need to decide when to essentially "retire" heroes in order to benefit from their strengths in future generations, without them dying before their time.It would be good to see one or two new classes be brought into the fray, there would obviously be alot of work required to maintain the excellent balance that already exists, however the addition of extra classes would prevent it from getting stale too quickly.I also enjoy the random events that require decisions to be made and years later the full repercussions of these events are revealed, for good or bad, it really makes you take the time to think on your choices, as you can't simply save / load a file to rethink your decision.I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good turn-based strategy with roguelike elements, a gameplay and difficulty similar to the likes of X-Com, however it is certainly by no means an X-Com clone.

number of helpful: 18 of 38 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												A lot of what is said in reviews is spot on and even more is complete and total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t...Balance: Flawless. People saying they loved XCOM EU/EW and hate this game because "it isn't balanced" is hilarious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Massive Chalice does a better job at getting me to bring one of each unique class into each battle than any other tactical game I have played. You have a melee class, a grenadier style class, and a ranged class as you three base classes and then merging bloodline will create hybrids. Having one of each base class was a must for me playing and I enjoyed it.Story: Decent. This is made better with the fantastic voice acting and great visuals. This is yet another claim that boggles my mind- that the "story is boring and XCOM is better". The "story" was by FAR the weakest part of XCOM, "aliens are here, kill them, they only have one master ship, kill it". If you are playing either of these two games for "the story" you are in the wrong genre friend...Combat: Decent. This one is true. Other tactical games (such as XCOM EW/EU as well as Divinity Original Sin) have produced a much more solid combat experience. Every fight is on a flat surface with elevation never being introduced. Some games (like Divinity) get away with their fights being only on one surface but it can be felt in this game. There is enough tactical fun and content here to make combat fun and thought provoking but not enough depth or inovations for it to be a selling feature.Bloodlines: Great. This one has not been done well in any other tactical game save for some Fire Emblem games (which have even LESS tactical combat) and it has been done well here. Relics that get passed down bloodlines and playing "game of thrones" with regents is great. This is a huge selling feature for this game, if it does not interest you then buying the game would most likely be a mistake.Length: Weak. Each "generation" needs to be 4x as long with 4x as many battles. You can beat the game in 15-20 hours. This is (IMO) the single greatest problem with the game- the combat was never a selling feature (IMO) for the game and didn't need that much more content (if any) but the world size as well as content feels lacking. It is a shame that mods were never really a deal as a "Long War" mod for this game I would frankly enjoy far more than on XCOM EU...Tower Defense: Weak. I add this in as well even though combat doesn't reflect a "tower defense" style of play the "defending the heart of your country as things come in from the borders" style of play is present in the "world view" aspect of the game. I am a huge fan of "no lost countries" and would never, EVER lose a single country in XCOM- that CANNOT happen in this game. This game is a "hold out long enough to win" style of game with countries/areas that will fall regardless of your actions. I hate this, it would be the first thing I mod out or at least give some way/option to fight to retake it (like in XCOM LW).Overall: You want a decent turn based tactical game with country management and bloodline control there is nothing better on the market. If you want pure tactical combat with nil story and nil country management and nil bloodline control then this isn't for you. If you are somewhere inbetween then I would still recommend, I would just suggest picking it up on sale.

number of helpful: 18 of 38 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is just an initial review for the 7.2 hours I've managed to put into the game so far (year 150) so please keep that in mind.I feel that Massive Chalice wants to be more than just a tactics game, more than just an empire game. Where the game is now, however, it's not /quite/ there - but it more than easily has that potential. The attacks on your kingdom force you to truly build up a team of heroes that rival the forces of the Cadence, while at the same time making you choose which of those heroes will carry on a bloodline, teach trainees, and who will carry on the research. The balancing act is, by itself, a game that put me to a bit of a challenge, at first.As I said, I feel that this game wants to do two things at once, which is fine. But in the wise, immortal words of Ron Swanson; "Never half♥♥♥♥♥two things, whole♥♥♥♥♥one thing." My first playthrough (which ended up with me having zero hunters and no idea how to get out of that bind) was a complete flop - But it frustrated me in a way that I /wanted/ to find out how to remedy that situation. So, I started anew and quickly built up three keeps, stocking them each with one of the classes, figuring this would keep my army strong with new recruits and my sagewrights pouring in.How wrong I was. Quickly, it became apparent that I had partnered with each of my regents, Queenmakers. My female population boomed! That wouldn't have been an issue if most of my males had survived past the Regent's deaths (I've only had one hero die on the battlefield, so far, my regents just refused to die). As it was, I struggled to balance out my kingdom. It was wonderful and challenging just enough because you cannot replace regents, you cannot pull back your sagewrights. But now, in year 150, I've found that simply bolstering your ranks with new recruits from the research/build option, that's never an issue.But it should be! And while, yes, I should be able to recharge my kingdom with new blood, I find that I'm able to do so easily and without effort because of this; There's simply not enough to build/research that I can't spare 15 years to recruit three times in a row. And this leads me to my next point...The combat is fantastic! I love when the Cadence get the balls to move into my territory and the balancing act of which territory will get an extra corruption. Now, being in Early Access I understand the sameness over and over, but each battle I try to go into with a fresh perspective because the enemy types aren't always the same. However I've come to realize that currently, hunters are extremely powerful. Not because they're overpowered, but because Alchemists and Caberjacks just aren't up to snuff yet.The Alchemist does have a nice aoe attack, but it pales in comparison to a hunter because of the lack of vials. And while they're "weak" physically, most of mine do actually punch things pretty hard - so they're not totally useless after they've blown their load all over the field, but I just feel like having the hunter would do more for me. Caberjacks, on the other hand, hit like Optimus Prime and if you equip them in the Bulwark armor they're actually fairly tough tanks. But they lack the range of their hunter counterpart and still have the same HP pool on most heroes.Now, I know these things can be breeded out through genetics of your bloodlines, and that's fine. I just don't feel like the other two classes are quite up to par just yet - which is terrible because it caused me to build another two keeps for more hunters and another for Caberjacks (as a just in case) but I completely disregard my alchemist line except for Sagewrights. Which, in a weird way actually works out well because I've bred them to be intuitive and that helps research times. Except, I'm out of things to research.So, in closing, Massive Chalice has great potential and while it is still in Early Access, it's the perfect time to get this kind of feedback in for the developers to look at. Again, only halfway through my (second) playthrough and I can see replayability being a thing, because I want to know how some of those random events turn out in other ways. If you're on the fence about this game, I highly recommend it, especially if Double Fine can keep up the work.

content:

Early Access Review
								Double Fine has delivered.  Massive Chalice is everything that they said it would be in the original Kickstarter.  The alpha/beta have been fully playable, with no game breaking bugs, just some minor balance/pacing/difficulty issues that they've been working hard to fix before the final release.  What's also impressive is how much of the development they did "in the open" with near constant team stream videos and blog posts.  Most importantly, though, the game is fun to play.  If you enjoyed X-Com, Enemy Unknown, you'll like this game, as the gameplay is similar, but the bloodlines system adds a lot of depth and makes you feel more of a connection with your heroes.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok, so I'm already 7 hours into this game according to steam, and I bought it yesterday. (wha... how'd that happen?)I am REALLY digging this game. The spirit of the game has the right amount of snarkiness / playfullness and is completely unforgiving (in a good way). I highly recommend giving this game a shot - it already feels finished enough that you can do a solid, fun playthrough- and I expect it will only improve as we get closer to a 1.0 release.I'm playing this on an incredibly outdated (mid 2011) macbook air, so the settings are cranked WAYYY down, but I have to say that even on the lowest settings the game is both playable and INTERESTING TO LOOK AT! I have a better computer that I haven't had a chance to download it on (it's my DOTA2 box that sits at my friends house) but I'll be doing that for sure the first chance I get - I hear the art direction is really amazing and it shines through even on crappy settings.

number of helpful: 13 of 28 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								So long story short, this is an amazing squad based tactical game with some awesome decision making/advanced planning thrown in. However if you arent convinced, here are some pros and cons1. Awesome tactical combat once you get the hang of it2. A good mix of humorous and serious tones3. Gorgeous art style.4. Challenging but rewarding leveling5. Great difficulty, challenging but never unfair6. Character breeding. Take two characters together, make a keep, slap them together, and boom! Warrior baby! or lowly peasant baby, all depends really.7.Ability to research different upgrades, buildings, and character skills for different play styles8. passing of weapons of fallen heroes9. The story plays over 300 years so you have to plan in advanced to get good heroes that were created due to the hard work of their ancestors who you controlled in battle leading to a lineage of heroes.10. Random events occur as time passes and you get to pick the result, each with its own consequencesAll is not perfect however. There are a few drawbacks1. Only 3 classes2. Not too many abilities for each class3. The tutorial is a bit convoluted. It confused me more than it should have. It plays like all other tactical games but you wouldnt know by the diagram they throw at you.4. Not a lot to reasearch5. A lack of options in most areas. There are a few but not nearly enough

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												The game has great combats but there's also many weaknesses in the design of the global management mainly, plus many design choices of the global management that I don't like.The main negative points that are more or less objectives:- The UI looks cool and is ok for combats, but overall it is rather weak on many points because of a bad "ease of use" design, like bizarre cumbersome lists, inability to check keeps during events or during some other actions, lack of switch tool like see next hero detail or see next keep detail, many more. You'll get more or less used to it, but it's still a rather weak point except in combat where it could be improved but it is ok overall.- There's a lot of random spread into the global management but they are too much pure random, much more procedurally generated random could only be much better.- There's too many rules or effects not explained, it's a design choice of the game copying a bad design element of old classic roguelike, it's still a bad design even if some old classics used it.- The strategy layer coming from the general management is rather thin. It's more a management game than a strategy game, few strategic choices, not much opportunities to setup plans and adapt plans. The game is much more about series of micro decisions. To be clear new xcom is a bit better on this but not good either.But for me the weakest points of the game are design choices that some other type of players could enjoy, the main points are:- The general management is designed with a spirit of high negativity, it's copying a design approach of old classic roguelike. It's not a matter of difficulty, it's a matter of being negative. For example you have to bother with paralytic, asthmatic, mostly blind, drunk, sterile, nervous heroes is just pointless and highly unpleasant for me. It's honestly my main grip against the game, and without this I'd probably vote thumb up, perhaps.- Mixed classes are by themselves a good design but how you get heroes classes linked to keeps marriages is generating a high lost of control of classes used, and I don't like at all this. That destroys the ability to do thematic replays based on a choice of a set of classes. That point is also a major reason why I am overall more negative than positive about the game.- There's many events along a campaign play, the problem is your choice will be random until you know the answers. The events are a good idea but I don't like at all to have to do random choices, and it's infuriating when it leads to a huge penalty and a smash in your face.- Too much random in the global management gameplay, that's tedious for me.For the sake of balance, I should add that the game has also good and even great points:- The combats are very interesting with both depth and tactical diversity at your disposition. And don't listen players complaining Hunters are only valid or that the game has no tactical depth, it's just they don't know play the game.- Despite there's only a relative random generation of combats areas, it's still working rather well and don't feel repetitive. It could be better but overall it's a good point.- The aesthetic choice of the game could seem bizarre at first, but it works very well, it looks rather nice once you admit the approach, and such aesthetic will never look old. On that aspect the UI is successful too and has a nice and marking look. It's too bad that the "ease of use" of the UI isn't as good.- The events are a good idea to setup a story mood along a play, and that works rather well, too bad that the choices you have to do for those events are too much random until you know the events/choices/consequences.Overall only players that like a lot either pure random and negativity spirit, either squad combats, should try this game. Other should apply a lot of caution. Myself I'm in second category and don't really regret my buy, but it's definitely for me a highly irritating and relatively frustrating game.

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Massive Chalice combines aspects of tactical squad-based games like XCOM with a eugenics simulator to create a pretty unique strategy experience. Broadly speaking, the game divides into two distinct segments: the "grand" strategy map, where you'll mostly make choices with regards to things like what to research, who to marry to whom, how to react to certain events etc., which are interrupted by enemy attacks in the tactical maps, which play out very similarly to XCOM missions if without quite as much detail or tactical flexibility.There are some genuinely intriguing design decisions here - marrying off heroes of two separate classes will create hybrid classes, opening up new options in the tactical maps. High-level heroes will leave behind heirlooms when they die, letting their legacy live on through those relics (which can also be levelled). The Cadence (the evil guys) will always attack more than one region at a time, leaving you to make broader strategic choices as to how to defend your territory with the ultimate aim of surviving for the 350 or so years the game spans.The graphics are charming, albeit simplistic. They do fit the theme of the game, which is light-hearted and fun. That doesn't mean it's a simple game; it's just simple to get into. The controls are easy to pick up, but it's the broader context of the game that's harder to master. Building lasting bloodlines, ensuring a sufficient diversity of hero classes through shrewd marriages and the like...all the while cheering for the battlefield victories of individual heroes you'll come to know, love and mourn as they pass. RIP SpaceJesus Doodlebats, gone but never forgotten.

number of helpful: 39 of 81 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I backed Massive Chalice on Kickstarter and it's probably one of the best decisions I've made, in terms of money spent on games.The game plays like long-form, fantasy X-Com. You control a squad of heroes against a force of maurauding monsters. Instead of aliens, however, you fight the Cadence. Demonic entities that can corrupt the land, steal experience from your champions, and even age those they touch by years at a time. Your champions wield bow, flask, and caber in the defence of your kingdom.Your advantage in this war? An immortal king (the player) who can guide the battles of the nation over the course of centuries, and the Chalice, which can charge up over this time to lay waste to the Cadence on a global scale.Over the course of 300 years, you'll research new weapons and technologies, build keeps and other fortifications, and most importantly, guide the destinies of heroic bloodlines. For while the combat is similar in concept to X-Com, you do not recruit new heroes out of thin air. They must be bred. The strongest champions become regents, and through arranged marriage, their children are made stronger. Weak traits are weeded out, strengths are promoted over the course of generations. Will your bloodlines become strong enough to make the final push to wipe out the Cadence?With the latest patch to the beta game, there are now Hybrid classes that greatly mix up the combat, and I have been having a blast. (although the pure Hunter, Alchemist, and Caberjack classes are still fun). Personally I like the ****/Alchemist hybrids the best.In short, the game gives us tactical, squad-based combat on an epic scale, and somehow makes Eugenics fun.Go play it.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Massive chalice? It might as well be called "Massive Time Sink", but that's not necessarily a bad thing. Like similar games in the tactical campaign genre, this one involves a lot of careful planning and unnecessary soldier deaths. The thing that sets it apart, however, is the breeding system, where family lines continue on through the ages, passing down training and useful traits. While these bloodlines are kept mostly safe in keeps, it's possible through poor luck or poorer planning to lose one entirely-- which keeps things interesting.Basically, if you enjoy short rounds of tactical combat spread over prolonged strategic campaigns, this is an excellent game. It's strongest when you're making interesting decisions, and the random events keep things lively, but it's not as fun when you've made a fatal mistake but still have an hour of gameplay before the inevitable loss claims you.

								I think this game is great so far. It is XCOM with a twist, however I think that the game does need a little worktwo things that come to mindTime passes to quick, the maximum amount of missions one hero seems to get to go on is 3 (4 if you start them at 15 years old and they live to be 87). Building up one unit almost has no pay off, apart from being able to give someone in his/her bloodline a boost when they die.Enimies get really hard really fast, I have heard this complaint from others, but it's true, I have completely wiped a few times. This challenge is part of what makes a game like Massive Chalice great, but I think it is just a bit too hard (an no difficulty option to make it a little easier on you.)It's a great game and I'm sure that Double Fine is going to be able to make it really wonderful.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								In this game, you are an immortal and immobile ruler of the kingdom besieged by evil poisonous monsters. The talking Chalice is going to purge the monsters in 300 years, so you have to survive that period with the help of the warriors you recruit, manage and guide in turn-based X-COM-like battles. There is a twist - be it a kingdom management projects or hero level-ups, it takes long time. LONG time. Years, decades, literally. So the value of each investment and decision is becoming critically high.Your heroes are aging and dying of old age, as well as in battle, so you have to account for it by retiring them from active roster to form a family and produce offspring - your new cannon fodder. You can also retire them to research and training instituions- with age heroes get increased "wisdom" property, which is good for those activities. One hero can only participate in a few actual battles, so you can't get a fighter from first to last level in a single lifetime.  This way, it becomes important to find the right time to retire your leveled-up hero to the family life - for the children of leveled-up characters will be automatically pre-leveled-up in accordance with their parents, and so can continue the advancement.Good stuff:-Beautiful design-The feeling of advancing despare and desperation, the all-powerful Time and Death.-Gameplay is easy to pick up and is quite enjoyable.Not so good stuff:-Story is rudimentary-There are not a lot of options for research/kingdom management, and even less of those are really worth consideration.-The game is "evil"-tough. I'll elaborate on this. In turn based combat games, like X-COM, there is usually a strong feeling of risk and the enemy outgunning you. It's tough, as screw-ups can lead to devastating effects for the whole team, and you have to take chances, think strategically and even just pray for a lucky outcome. This is part of the appeal, because it adds suspence and a semblance of realism.In this game, though, the toughness is not of a risky, but of a depressing kind most of the time. Your team is screwed up from the start: your options for strategical advance and recon are limited by abilities/landscape. Also, there is almost no chance for blind luck to give you joy once in a while. I do understand that it's the part of the idea that your fighters will die messily and often. But mission after mission of "we are blindly rushing in a pre-arranged death-trap" kills fun rather sooner than later.Still, all in all, it's an interesting game with a potential, as it's still in EA stage.

Early Access Review
								MASSIVE CHALICE is worth buying if you're a fan of XCOM, or like the idea of long term management along with tactical combat. The management seems more complex than XCOM, but at the end of the day you're just looking at numbers. Combat isn't as complex as XCOM since there isn't cover or many advanced tactics, but it is still fun. The game will last you about 15-20 hours, and it does have some good replayability since you can take a different research route. The only things left to really add to the game are difficulty levels and IRON mode, which will probably just prevent you from loading your game whenever.A video shows most of what the game is about:

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								8/10 This game is amazing.The gameplay is fun and involved, the lineage system is truly revolutionary.Would've 9/10 + except for a few things. I know its still in beta, but getting past around year 100 is extremely difficult, to the point of impossible, and the gameplay has too much missing. (i know this sounds silly, missing is a good mechanic that can make things more lifelike), but in a strategy based game, especially at higher levels, it makes it very hard to plan attack strategies around the immensly strong enemies when you miss so often. each character has their sweet spots and you can even upgrade an item to make them more accurate, but it is still stressful. The alchemist which are supposed to be weak units that must hit from afar only start with 5 bombs, and you have to be within 2-3 spaces to get anything higher than a 60%, so they die. alot. even melee units, some units will get around a 60% when attacking at point blank. yet some get 100%. im not quite sure how this is supposted to work. Its a fantastic game, however I don't believe a strategy game's difficulty should be based around missing your target or not. (especially when the enemies have 4x your health and they dont miss half as much as you do, and deal more damage).

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is being worked on intensely and things are changing all the time, so much of this is subject to change.Short version: It's fun. It's hard. It's relatively bug-free.MC seeks to address a lot of the issues with squad-based tactics games like X-COM, primarily by making character death less of an issue. The fact that even your best warriors will eventually die of old age means that losing a few in battle doesn't NECCESARILY require a restart of the entire mission. Heck, if they die in battle they might turn into a magical weapon for your other warriors to use.That being said, there are issues, though most of them just come with the territory in this type of game. There are a lot of things to research and build, and all of them take a long time. If things start going badly for you, don't expect them to stop. Sure, you have a crucible to train your new recruits, but without someone to staff it, it does no good. If you find yourself low in units and your birthrate isn't good, you can go scour for new recruits, but it takes years.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												What I can say about Massive Chalice is odd. It's a game that is at the same time very neat, and very clunky.For example the combat (one of the things you'll be doing the most) is laid out in a neat way, the UI is good. You get a lot of information (although not enough like the game not telling you if you'll be in the range for a melee attack) without it cluttering the interface.That however doesn't make the actual combat any better. While at first it might be enjoyable to experiment with various classes you quickly discover strategies that work best for your current line-up and stick to them.For example if you play with a lot of hunters you'll be doing a lot of sneaking and alpha striking the enemy to blow him up before he can react, as kaberjacks you'll notice that enemies take damage by getting knocked back into walls AND into units. So you'll abuse that fact for more damage+stun potential, alchemists are really only good against the weakest enemies in the game. so after the start they only really serve to make kaberjack and hunter hybrids. But that creates a problem for the other game mechanics.The breeding. It is supposed to be a big part of the game but really it turns into a chore. The mechanics are never explained properly so you have to do a lot of guesswork to understand how to do it properly. It is important to remember that your kids will not only get the traits of the parents, but also possibly random ones or traits from the OTHER members of the family tree, OR perks that you didn't even know the family has. This is extremely frustrating in the early game and if not managed properly becomes a problem in the mid and even late game.Imagine this scenario. You decide that you'll base your early game on kaberjacks (and you have to decide who to base it on early because you only get one castle at start). Cool. You built your castle, you find a good young couple with a high fertility rating and good kaberjack stats and mush them together. Recipe for success right? No.Now it took your super fertile mating pair anywhere between 0 and 40 years to pop their first baby. They might NEVER get one even though the release day patch supposedly altered the numbers. But hey, there is a kid! Oops he's asthmatic and anaemic. So he can't run and he has reduced hp. WHy is that?! Oh because both family trees had those perks hidden in their genes and you had absolutely NO way of knowing that. Enjoy.Now imagine you're doing this for 300 in-game years while having to constantly bring in new blood (and new bad traits) because upkeeping a family that is provided for is apparently a really hard task.So yeah, neat idea, pretty dull and clunky execution. Same you could say for most of the game.Honestly if this is how Double Fine keep doing things I think I'll just stop buying things from them altogether.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Still some things need to be imporved... But a must buy game!Overall on of the best stratagy games out there!  (NEW, game release review!) The release of a game update made the game so so so much better! its like a complete new game, a DLC to the game you can say.  I really like how you can feel so close to your heros/family in this game.... and you scream at the computer if one dies! i have done that so many times, that i felt embaressed when i did it.  My brother comes running up the stairs, "are you ok brother!?" then I scream at him, "no way brother! raphtin potter died!"  I love the main map, I love how the tec works in the game, but I wish I could research two tecs at the same time. I wish there were more buildings to build.  But I only want more in the game because I like is so much!  I love the time line in how it works... after years your heros die and you need to breed a new set of heros every 40 years or so, and your tec and buildings take years to build and research.  most of what I wrote about is in the battle, but everything in the main map screen I really like. With the new controller support it feels like a completely different game, but I say that because I enjoy playing with the xbox 360 controller.... I give Massive Chalice a 9/10!!!1. I am playing on a surface pro one, which I can play games like crisis 2, whicher 2, skyrim... but this games graphics are not as good as xcoms and xcom works way better then this.  MC is very laggy even after putting it in windowed and revolution low, and taking off all the visual effects.  I played Gang Beasts from doubled fine and it has the same problem!!!!  I hope they fix this(UPDATE: FIXED GRAPHICS :)2. voices are good, but they need to put the voises together so there are no pauses in the cinamatics.  Also they need to add more voices into the game for the characters.  After they kill someone a comic book animation pops up, making it look like the character say something, why not make the character just have a voice over? also the cinamatics are very boring, make the speaks voices together without pauses(FIXED THE CINAMATICS :) but they still need to add voice overs for the families once they kill a bad dued)3. I am not sure why, but one of my guy attacks a ghost looking guy, and he does 2 damage (which it said he would do 11-15 damage), then another guy with the same weapon attacks and kills it doing 15 damage to it.  (UPDATE: STILL NOT FIXED :(4. (New) They need to make the heros more memorable in some way.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's early access so beware if you're not willing to put up with that. Right now it's kind of a mixed stew for me. I like the concept and much of what's implemented. Haven't had time to play alot yet but I can list some +/- at least.+The gfx style is kind of an aquired taste but it reminds me of games such as the Interstate '76 series. It's quite nice in it's simplicity.The Bloodline Genetics system adds some depth to the game.The voiceover for the chalice ... ghosts?Fighting. It's not very complex but satisfying, mostly.Easy to get started but from what I can tell mastering it will take some practice.-Randomness. Yes there's always gonna be some degree of randomness but I feel it's a bit harsh sometimes. Like spawning in the middle of a big pack of cadence, assigning two healthy middle age heros to a castle and having one of them dying in a year with no children. Etc. If bad luck like this was rare I guess it would be fine but it's happened a couple of times in my short playtime.I think the time progresses a bit fast. Now don't get me wrong I don't want the game itself that much slower, build and research times don't need to be longer. But I'd like to spend a little more time with my heros. To get to know them better during combat etc. Mabe more frequent encounters would work as well.About half of the cadence I've faced so far explode making Caberjacks alot less useful than hunters and alchemists. This might work itself out when I get further and can start upgrading armor, get them to higher levels etc. But early game I don't really see the point to them. The cadence that don't explode can be killed just as easy by the two ranged classes. And while caberjacks get charge at level 1 and it has a knockback it has cooldown and if it doesn't finish the cadence off it can just walk up and explode next to the caberjack when your turn ends. Would be good if even at low levels with no upgrades to gear caberjacks had more health or better damage mitigation so they had better survivabilty,

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fantastic game in most aspects. The musical direction is superb, the combat has its own unique yet familiar feel, and the game will have you do some selective breeding. The things I feel that could use some work are the usefulness of classes, such as the caberjack, which is a melee brute-like class that I let die out everytime I had one, not on purpose, but because I gave Hunters and Alchemists priority. The hybrid classes are what filled my ranks however, each one is unique and they mix classes from both of the parent's classes. The decision you make is what traits you want to have your future soldeirs to carry. I binged this game, mainly because that's how I intake these things. The game is fantastic and I will be doing another run through because the game was a bit too easy, and it was kind, I got hawkeyed and longetivity traites for most of my beginnner soldiers. So seeing them die at the age of 70 was sad but I felt good knowing that others can die at 40~. If anything the game's ending (no spoilers) could use a bit more of an expansion or some work, I just think it needs that "legacy" feel as the whole game is literally built around legacies, but YOUR legacy. It could be sequel bait(I don't mind it on this occasion because I'm down for a sequel). The hate I see on forums is based on it being DF and spacebase. Frankly however, this game differs and seems to have had a lot of time and effort put into it. If you buy this game, you will NOT regret it. You'll be fighting the cadence for a long time...almost 300 years.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								WARNING: Do not start playing this game until you have several days of free time open. At first glance, this seems like a fairly standard turn-based strategy game, but it is far more. Managing bloodlines within your nation will leave you immersed for hours and hours. In fact, I often found that actual time seemed to speed forward like the in-game time! The combat itself is a lot of fun, but I got a rush of adrenaline every time I activated the "time forward" button. Seeing families live and die while passing legacies onto their children is really damn cool. In addition, having to make decisions with real consequences is a nice touch to add to the immersion.  This game has far exceeded my expectations when I backed it on Kickstarter (full disclosure!).

Early Access Review
								First Review ever on steam!One it's in early access so there is more to come but form what I've played it's got alot of potential to become a very great game.ok my review!If you liked X-Com: Enemy unknown, Grand Strategy games, state breading (pokemon style) and a simple but hard game play. Try this game!The combat comes down to a very few things, range attacks, AoE, melee and knock back. The enemies have there own strengths and weaknesses, but though the use of your Heros you can over come the enemies (mosly by combos of keep you enemy away and taking them down one at a time). The story is well something intresting, you can have it narrated straight forwerd or silly. The combat can be overwellming when you have to many enemies to fight off at once (4 or more different provoked enemies will kill someone or your whole party)What I hope comes to the full version is-more classes-AI boss enemies (maybe evolving like you heros though some breading)-AI that know how to run away to fight again with there fellow enemies-AI that try to flank or trick you into a fight-more weapons-making your own custom Families/House (banner and Names)All in all really good game, you may find your self saying " oh just a few more years, just a bit longer".

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								The potential for this game is through the roof, however there are a few issues that hinder the experiences.1. Hard to form any type of emotional bond with a character when they due of old age after only fighing in 2 or 3 fights in their entire lifetime.  With no real emotional connection to a character, permadeath isn't really that gripping.2. The child birth rate is embrassingly low.  I was always low on heros about ~30 years into the game.  These heros up their game.3. My biggest complaint has to be on the accuracy of attacks.  The game says these heros have trained their entire life to fight the Cadence, however they are painfully bad at landing attacks.  I've had turns where I've had improbably bad luck (a 95% missed, a 90% missed, 80% missed, then 2 60%s missed, same turn) and this happens A LOT.  I believe the percentages reported are not accuracte to the actual chances.  Maybe there is something I am missing.  Instead of having a hunter having a 50% chance to do 10 damage, give them a 90% chance to do 5-6 damage.  This removes the feeling that your hero (who has trained for this their entire life) is painfully incompent who can only hit a target 10 feet away 50% of the time.  Again, its a good game.  Needs more polish, but it looks promising.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												1 min in: Wait this is made by double fine studios? Ok I really hope that isn't an omen6 min in: Oh lord this is hilarious! There are so many factions to pick from. LIke there are 20 pages alone for just the ones beginning with the letter S. They're arranged in alphabetical order which is nice. All of these are pretty great like this one battle cry "For Glory!...or something." Oh man I bet this game is going to be great.10 min in: Okay picked my houses, now to go on to the game. Okay so I'm some immortal commander, giant talking chalice with two spirit things. And some kind of encroaching darkness on the land I have to keep back for the next 300 years so the chalice can charge up its super awesome attack to vanquish it for good. Okay why didn't you ever do this sooner? I guess I'll accept it for now. Oh look an attack is going on, better go take care of it.12 min in: Hey this looks like xcom, oh cool all the characters have different traits, like faint of heart which will make you weaker when your allies die. That sounds like something from xcom. At least all the houses i chose are what these guys are from. Oh whats this? These guys have kids? That sounds pretty cool. I can have different blood lines, this is going to be sweet.13 min in: Hey...why do these controls look a lot like xcom's...14 min in: Okay time to move my guys...Wait thats how you move them...Oh no this is exactly like Xcom's movement system.15 min in: Hey look an enemy, alright so how do we...wait what? Enemy in sight...darkness outside the field of view...Oh you have got to be kidding me. This is XCOM! Its literally the same game but in a fantasy setting. Okay maybe I'm just judging it a little too early. After all if this is like XCOM, its a very long game before you learn everything. i'm sure there will be mechanics that make it vastly different from XCOM.20 min in: Seriously the combat is a direct rip off of XCOM, except this time only one guy can shoot things that are 2 feet in front of him and still miss. You even have units that use grenades! Oh I'm sorry "Alchemists" that throw "flasks" Yeah nice save there.22 min in: Okay beat the first battle, now on to the non-combat section of the game. I bet this is where it will diffirentiate itself from XCOM, i mean there is no way they'd copy that as well...right?24 min in: Oh so i can assign regents to a keep, putting them in charge of it with a partner. Then they procreate, have kids and they also become heroes which i can take into battle, or assign to lead into a keep? Hey thats pretty neat.28 min in: Okay I took care of everything here, now i just click on that play button there....Oh come on! You copied that from XCOM too!? The map is just like the base from XCOM, come on double fine! Whatever, maybe theres more than meets the eye. After all 300 years are supposed to pass, there is going to at least be more mechanics than what i'm seeing right now.30 min in: Alright it appears 5 years have passed and, oh a new battle, alright lets go to that region and protect it. Now lets go to the screen and select my heroes to fi-ITS THE SAME AS XCOM'S! THE DEPLOYMENT SCREEN IS LITERALLY XCOM'S BUT JUST WITH THEM STANDING OVER A CHALICE! OH COME ON! Whatever just lets see these classes. Alchemist, Caberjack, Hunter, and...Is that it? Are you seriously telling me there are only 3 classes for the heroes? Really!? You couldn't even copy XCOM on that with their 4? Are you kidding me?32 min in: There are lot of these Rupture guys, they explode and leave behind some kind of acid that damages units caught in the acid...just like in XCOM.35 min in: More of these Rupture enemies? Geez is the whole level nothing but these guys?38 min in: Oh my god the whole level was nothing but those guys...44 min in: Alright i have all this stuff set up, my regents are making babies so I'll have future generations to lead, i built this guild to research new stuff for me, everythings going pretty good...wait what? A bunch of my guys died, how? Old age!? What! Okay I understand this game takes place over the course of years, but these guys were barely level 2! And they died in their 40's! They didn't even make it past 50. Whats the point of leveling these guys up when not even 10 minutes later they'll die of old age!?50 min in: Yay more babies born, some have grown up now, Rory is a bit of a grown up now, and he isn't too bad. He's a hunter, got the hawkeye perk, I think he'll make for a fine soldier.55 min in: Another battle...terrific.63 min in: Battle won, I'm done, I'm getting really sick of this.65 min in: Yo guild! You have literally contributed nothing so far! You have done nothing to benefit our fight against this darkness. What have you done at all? I keep giving you members that end up dying of old age, but yet you continue to do nothing. Fine whatever I'll just go build this citadel thing.67 min in: So you put units in here to train? Okay I'll put Rory in here, he did well in the last battle so leveling him up is a good idea.70 min in: Finally I found a use for you guild. Research this health potion thing to heal my soldiers up.72 min in: Another battle, another day. Yay...74 min in: Holy crap someone actually died!? Wow okay thats...I really don't care. You want to know why game? Because unlike XCOM I can't bring myself to actually care about the people i'm sending in to fight. I don't grow attached to them, and unlike with XCOM, I don't cry and mourn when one of them dies. Which since you are obviously ripping them off, is a blatant failure.78 min in: HOW DID YOU MISS!? EVEN WORSE HOW DID YOU NOT ONLY MISS, BUT THROW YOUR FLASK OFF A CLIFF!? YOU SOMEHOW NOT ONLY MANAGED TO MISS YOUR TARGET WITH A 85% CHANCE OF HITTING THEM, BUT YOU ALSO MISSED AND THREW IT OFF THE CLIFF! YOU MORON!80 min in: Oh hey look its some kind of blue lady enemy made of energy. Just like X-nope not going there. I saw her earlier but she never managed to hit me with her ranged attack.81 min in: WHAT! SHE DRAINS XP WHEN SHE HITS YOU!? AND YOU CAN LOSE AN ENTIRE LEVEL IF YOU'RE HIT ENOUGH, AND YOU ALSO STILL TAKE THE NORMAL HEALTH DAMAGE!? Even XCOM didn't do that and it was incredibly difficult without it! Don't pad your game out with artificial difficulty!85 min in: Wait the losing battle system is just like XCOM's but worse...My patience is thinner than ice right now..88 min in: You know its been a few decades now, when am I getting Rory back? I know he's not dead so...where is he? He seriously can't still be training.91 min in: Seriously I don't see any difference between this and XCOM.94 min in: Build a keep here, and...Hey that area i wanted to build something on is being attacked, I better take care of that.96 min in: Alright i'm in...level bland as ever, everything literally inferior to XCOM? Yep.97 min in: Oh look more Ruptures, and blue ladies, and a ball with two legs...you know I'm just over an hour in and yet this game still only has 3 enemy types? All of which are rip offs? I guess they have a motiff of ripping off, doing worse, and giving less with this game don't they?100 min in: Units are dying but I can still win this.105 min in: Okay make that 1 guy left, at least he's an alchemist. Sure he's low health but he can deal damage from a distance and his range attacks also have an area of effect, just use that move on the last two enemies that are right beside each other and I win the battle.108 min in:...He died...He threw it...and he failed so badly...it went back and hit him...killing him...He had a 95% chance of not only hitting them, but killing them too...and he somehow manages to throw the flask at himself...110 min in: ...ffffFFFUUUU-*screams of rage destroy everything in a 200 mile radius.*4/10 Get XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Double fine stopped fixing this game just a month after release, and it still has a lot of issues.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
												The haters are amateurs and misunderstand what this game is about; this is a game about farming dozens of Pokemon and then lamenting when those Pokemon die of old age before you could force them to breed with each other. All the combat / etc. exists only to setup that moment when you realize you're promoting weird inbreeding and you realize you are DEPRAVED.The tactical layer is purposely minimalistic, it's just enough of a battle system to support the family mechanics and timeline metaphor. Hello this attitude is REFRESHING. Like, dudes, not every game should need a wiki to understand it? Loading your game with junk is DESPERATE (e.g. Shadowrun is DESPERATE) and I'm glad this game had the confidence not to do that.PROS:- Doesn't care about fantasy garbage lore, it's silly in the right places and at the right times- Battles take like 15 minutes instead of an hour, yeah sorry XCOM I don't have all day- You get to treat humans like the cattle we areNOT-SO-PROS:- With no real concept of cover, archers are really overpowered, and it doesn't help when the game lets you upgrade them into INVISIBLE DEATH ARCHERS; this is a problem they couldn't have fixed without some serious overhauls to their line of sight systems... the alternative is to make archers really inaccurate, but arbitrary % failure mechanics are never fun, so I guess they decided to just let archers be the best, and I think I agree with that- The campaign is too long, 300 years is a cool number but it's really too long, it probably should've been more like 200 years

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								I don't understand some of the negative reviews, every game has faults. But especially here the good outweighs the bad.Good:A great Tactical Turn Based RPG/Breeding Simulator. Aside from units seemingly not having "Facing". I'm not always doing the same thing with my capital either so far, a few times I've researched more pools of heroes to have more people to breed due to an irritating loss due to a few mistakes in combat facing a new type of enemy. This one time one of my forts was empty, so I set a 1 year old as the regent and married him to a 3 year old girl because I was low on choices (despite not knowing how likely they would be to breed). Then they had babies twice right away at ages 16 and 17. I was like "Success!". I feel the game gives you "enough" choice. For example, I had the choice of defending an area with no blight but I would get more XP for killing stuff, whereas the other place already had blight but I would only get a baby girl for defending it. It would be more risky to let the blight spread where it is already, but more rewarding for my heroes to take the non-blighted land.Not Good or Bad:Some people complain about the graphical style, saying it has "Bad graphics". At first it was jarring for me. But as I played about an hour into it, the style just works. It reminds me of some of the art in Civ, just in 3-D. As your heroes age, it shows in their faces. This simplified style works wonders here, as you can tell they are older just by looking at their faces. The style remains consistant throughout the game and works well in most if not all areas. It also gives it more of a painted fantasy storybook look. I wouldn't change it, but adding some new particles or lightning might further boost the look.Things I would improve:Free equipments. I think the research time should be cut and you should have to "build" equipments consuming monster parts. If you lose a group out in the field you lost those equips, if you lost one dude out in the field, but you won, you get his equips back. It just bugs me a little that once you research something, you immidiately get 100+ free items through the course of the game.Bad:Crucibles are too hard. There are ways of dealing with every enemy and situation in the game (so far) that I've found out by using each class's different skills (Clobberjacks for stunning things at right times, bombing enemies from around structures, using the hunter to scout ahead a bit, etc). Except for Crucibles. They seem to outrange you, and not only that they can kill any ranged person in one shot because they do like 14+ damage. If you use both actions in your turn and "ran" into the sight of one, you are dead as soon as it's their turn. Even Clobberjacks like level 5 with the second teir armor seem to go down to like 1/3rd hp. Since they are ranged it is sometimes hard if not impossible to get to them in time to stun them too. You either catch them around a corner and stun/bomb/kill before it's their turn, or you get unlucky and have to fight them in the open. I found on a level where there are more than 2 Crucibles, I should always expect to lose a guy. Even the brute kockback teleporting fist dude can be dealt with, but these crucibles...

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												The important thing to note is that it is a strategy RPG. This means moving each individual piece across a map to remove Fog of War until you see the enemy and then, finally dealing with them. In addition, some of the enemies blow up when you kill them and some of your characters only do melee damage. . .  so you have to deal with only using them in melee range, but also not killing the enemies that blow-up with them. It doesn't have the speed, long sight lines, and variety of ranged attacks that made XCOM an enjoyable strategy RPG either.I'm in love with the concept of Bloodlines and family traits for a generation-spanning RPG, but the appeal of that is killed by the fact that the game is a strategy RPG. Additionally, I imagined handsome heroes growing up from adolescents who are learning their craft to young adults honing it, to mature adults achieving their legacy, to elders securing and nurturing it, but the art is so stylized that the humans look monstrously mishapen. . .  I'm not wondering what my hero's kids will look like because it will just be some flavor of ugly. Unfortunately, Massive Chalice's ideas had some great traits, but they were bread with some ideas with bad traits, the resulting offspring has suffered.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Massive Chalice, much like literally every Doublefine game produced since they decided they didn't need publishers or editors, is a bit confused. On one hand, it embraces the purity of XCOM2012-style (or perhaps I should say "traditional board game style") actions and has the trademark Doublefine carefully crafted aesthetic running through every level of the audiovisual presentation. On the other hand, it muddles everything with occasionally pointless RNG and has perhaps three too many systems going on simultaneously in the geoscape.Did I mention it's an XCOM(2012) CLONE? It's an XCLONE.There's some interesting bits resulting from the nessesarily disposable nature of your soldiers as you carefully curate their family trees to produce increasingly powerful and skilled individuals in the classes you want. It's a great twist on otherwise normal "level up your units" game design. Sadly this is muddled by the irritiating intrusion of RNG-based inheritance and a bunch of other random crap that turns what should be a selling point into a HR hellscape. Thankfully, the game doesn't randomly choose from the two choices you're presented with for skills when units level up.Did I mention it's an XCLONE? It's an XCLONE.The geoscape-level strategic game is neat because it forces you make a bunch of decisions all at once. You can search for new heroic bloodlines, build castles, or research new developments in fighting the corruption that threatens the world. Somewhat irritatingly, the game forces you to choose between building and researching because the titular Massive Chalice can only do one thing at a time. For plot reasons.Every so many years while you scan for alien activity charge the titular Massive Chalice to win the game, there's multiple incursions from aliens bad anime Symphogear's monster antagonists, the Noise the Cadence and you have to pick which pre-defined region you want to defend (based on rewards and the strategic situation) because you can only respond to one. Because plot reasons. The zones you don't respond to have their panic corruption meter increment by one tick.Did I mention it's an XCLONE? It's an XCLONE.Tactical combat is pretty fluid, even though there's a complete dearth of voicework for your units (one of the perils of letting Kickstarter backers do custom war cries for their backer house). Each unit gets two "actions" on your turn, and they all move at once. One class snipes with crossbows. One class uses grenades. One class hits things with a caber. There's a bunch of hybrid classes but they're just "Parent class, but with a twist from the other parent". Movement is done on a square grid, and units die pretty quickly on both sides. Okay so you may have noticed a bit of, shall we say, a theme so far. That theme being "XCOM2012, but with some wierd addons that muddle the everliving crap of XCOM2012's super tight design". Literally the only three big "design elements" that Doublefine didn't T.S. Eliot off of XCOM2012 are the house system, the endgame, and the fact that there are enemies that drain XP from your units when they hit them.Let's pause for a moment, and let that last one sink in. I'll allow that it's a pretty tiny bit of XP that gets shaved off, but level drain has never, ever, been a good design element. Not even in D&D. It's thematically a cool thing that the enemy does, but it's really emblematic of my issues with Massive Chalice as a whole: The game is so focused on style, mood, and its bloodline stuff that it sorta misses out on why XCOM2012 did things the way it did and tends to awkwardly stumble around when it's not winking at you. And the fact that the game absolutely nails its aesthetics so perfectly makes its 'original design, do not steal' gameplay all the more annoying.But no-one buys or plays Doublefine games for the gameplay, really.

								I just bought this game, and i'll say god..its difficult and fun. But it lacks just that tad bit more of content, such as customization, and maybe bigger maps, squads and that managing your kingdom feel. On its own however, its still wonderful. I'll list down the pros and cons and an overall opinion.Pros: Combat is wonderful, nearly like xcom though there's no cover mechanic but obstacles do block your line of sight.          Heroes can get married, and they can have offspring which mean more soldiers. (Dont think much of the FAMILY TREE, incest happens in this game as you 'll gradually lose heroes and lack the time to recruit more due to research),Which part of the kingdom you fight on will actually matter in terms of tactics you can use.Random events, which is always a +Mechanics, are just wonderful and cornering your opponent especially the big ones are important. RELICS though you might want a tier 2 weapon at the leastCons: You can only do one action at a time, so you cant construct, recruit  and research at the same time, can be a pro if you like the game to be more tough.Enemy AI can be dumb...... if there's a wall between you and them, they'll stick to the wall (in my instance it was a low wall and they just ran and stayed there, like fish in a barrel)You can't expand your squad and you also cant escape from battle just like in x-com = can be a +Opinion: It's a great game, i just wish for customization, kingdom management and maybe even some multiplayer. Try it you'll likely not regret buying and playing this gameOk finally finished.... its good not great but yeah, worth its price considering how much you can play and how many ways you can play.

Early Access Review
								I don't think the game is perfect but it's getting a 7/10 for me.  I like the art style/graphics it's a unique slant on similar games I've seen that keeps it fresh, and the voice acting is good. The AI is not what I consider the most tactical but also it's not lazy or glitchy either.  I also haven't run into any bugs which is great and I do like how parents of different classes will have babies that are mixed, and the passing down of traits is great too!  I didn't like the "you can't get attached to your characters because they're all going to die" thing. I GET it, everyone dies at some point and the lifespan thing is cool, but a character's full lifespan is actually very short in game time, so that man that spent all his life as an archer died of old age....at level 2... So I made sure I wasn't attached to anyone, but I couldn't really be anyway, also...being attached to characters is what makes a game fun. Maybe have a reasearch option that takes a lot to invest in but you get to make some units immortal? I mean with genetic manipulation and traits you're going to get super powered people anyway.    Overall though I really am enjoying the game. I hope other games make use of the genetic passing of traits systems, especially rpgs, though it's really unique in a strategy game like this!
