content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Review of the .96b betaShorter Review: A mixture of kingdom management, tactical battles, RPG, and hero breeding that  produces a satisfying game requiring thought and planning  Still being polished, but looking promising, and worth it if this is your area of interest.To review Massive Chalice, you need to start with the story.You're an Immortal regent, bound to a mysterious chalice holding the souls of past heroes.  That chalice is the only hope of your nation to cleanse it of the foul creatures that threaten it, the mysterious Cadence.  You'll rally heroes to fight, decide how to run the kingdom, and figure out how to survive.  Good thing you're immortal, because your heroes are not, and you'll need to plan how to use them, marry them, retire them, and pass on their legacies.  You've got a 300 year war ahead of you until the Chalice is powerful enough to end it, and everyone who started the battle with you will be dust when it's over . . .Massive Challice is a game that combines several play mechanics in a way that's easy to pick up - hard to master.  That's not an emplty statement - it's the truth, because the simple parts interact in many ways.* A straightforward, effective, but deep tactical battle game where heroes fight monsters.* An RPG system where you manage characters, equipment, and skills.* A straightforward, but detailed hero-breeding system where you establish lineages of heroes - who inherit traits, legacies, relics, and more.  * A (rather light) Kingdom management game that consists of making choices of battles, what to construct, and how to react to random events.In Massive Challice, you alternate battles with the Cadence and managing your kingdom and heroes over the course of 300 years.  One moment you're deciding who to attack, the next deciding what to build next, then responding to a random event, and finally trying to figure out if you should intermarry two heroic linages - then another battle may arise.  You're constantly scaling your strategy and tactics as you play, and how the different levels of the game mesh is a big part of the challenge and satisfaction - there's something about watching a new, well-trained hero of a class you unlocked due to an unusual marriage wield a weapon of his bloodline on the first go to cause massive damage.This means that this is a game of planning and management - even when you're whomping on the Cadence.  Because time is tight, resources are limited, and enemies are tough you are always constrained, always evaluating, always scheming - and often regretting.  Death is permanent, decisions aren't reversable (well unless you're using a save game and not playing in Iron Mode), and time and resources lost aren't easily reclaimed.  You will start over, you will reload saves - and if this is your kind of game, you will go back again and again.The combat, I think, deserves special note as it's well balanced.  There's 3 main classes and descendents via crossbreeding can unlock 6 more classes.  Stealth, special abilities, the right equipment, planning, and above all patience are requires for victory.  Pulling off massive kills and victories is quite satisfying and good planning is rewarded.  This is a precise, well done part of the game that was both deep yet completely accessible and intuitive.Regarding "Hero breeding" part of the game, it's straightforward on the surface - you get (or build) Keeps, appoint a regent and a partner, and they have kids (if they are capable of it).  Children inherit mental and physical traits and level up depending on parental experience - and other factors and structures.  The challenge is in avoiding bad traits, ensuring linages ("Relic" weapons are tied to a bloodline), balancing ages and genders, and determing what classes you want the next generation to be - you can easily mess up or destroy a bloodline.  Its fun, but At times can be wearing as you juggle combinations, though when you get a truly satisfying and fun character it's worth it.If there's a flaw in this release it's that the kingdom management part of the game still feels a bit light and there's not a lot of guidance.  The kingdom management is decent, but I'd like to see a few more options for research and development, or to at least see some unlockable options earlier so you know what there is to work forward to.  Research opens up more as the game progresses, but is rather lackluster for the first third.I do think the game lacks good tips and guidances for the more subtle situations like good breeding and so on.  Perhaps thats part of the challenge, but it can take away from the fun.The game's presentation is effective.  It has an angular look that puts me in mind of board games and low-poly games.  Character appearances change as they age.  The music, well done and subtle, sets a strange, almost somber mood (and is a strong point in the presentation).  The narration of the two souls in the chalice is decident to amusing, adding some levity and making you feel not so lonely (hey, you're immortal).I also feel the game should be praised for avoiding bog-standard fantasy classes.  There's no generic warriors, there's ram-wielding Caberjacks.  There's no thieves, there's stealty Hunters armed with enormous cannon-like crossbows.  No wizards either, but Alchemists who fling flasks of explosives with sharp-edged cestas called "Throwers."  As you breed heroes you unlock even more classes: Brewtalists, Trickshots, and more.It's rather refreshing, and the subclasses get interesting as well - I think my personal favorite is the Caberjack/Hunter fusion called a Shadowjack who can go into stealth mode DESPITE wielding an enormous two handed battering ram as a weapon.Yes, this game has characters who can spring out of the shadows and wack you with a giant log.And finally, let us close with the story.  Though the plot itself is compelling, I also enjoy how things happen to create your own narrative.  Random events change things.  Heroes grow, fight, sire offspring, die - or retire to teach or manage buildings (and then die).  You find yourself getting attached to bloodlines and some specific characters.  I still have fond memories of Freya "What's-Her-Face" Yurgin wielding the magical bow "Fang", or "The Beard" Nguyen the Brutal Brewtalist who retired to teach the next generations.I hope this game spawns others.  The idea of a kind of semi-procedural dynasty builder is compelling.I reccomend this game with a few limits - after all we're talking $30 bucks here.  If it was $20 it'd be no problem.* If this game sounds like it's up your alley, then it's worth it.  Certainly I have no regrets, feel I got my money's worth, and consider it replayable.* If the game sounds cool but you're not sure, wait for the full release to see what people say.  Its got a bit more tweaking and isn't exactly friendly to learn, so it's not something for everyone.I'm quite positive on this game.  I hope this launches a series, as the fusion of mechanics and long-term planning make this a fun, interesting, and satisfying game.

								Right, this one gets a cautious recommendation, mostly because of the combat. Also, points for being one of a few Early Access games that's actually complete, but just needs more content (you know, the way it's supposed to be).Story: the story is, you are a god-like entity brought into being by the Massive Chalice to save the lands from the encroaching Cadence, which you will do over the stretch of three hundred years. I liked the dual voices of the Massive Chalice, and there's nothing to really complain about on that front.Gameplay: You control different houses, and attempt to keep the bloodlines going throughout the three hundred years required for the chalice to activate while fighting off occasional incursions and doing research to improve the lands/heroes. It's a very good system, and the moment the game gave me a character in the Armstrong lineage named "Alex-Louis", the idea of passing down his Alchemist technique through the Armstrong line for generations never stopped being funny.The rub (and indeed, the caution part of this tale) is in the combat. This game most clearly takes influence from XCOM: Enemy Unknown and (to a lesser extent) Fire Emblem: Awakening. Problem is, it lacks the balance of the former, the insane depth of the latter and the expediency of both. One of the things I liked about those games (I'm using them for comparison because it's exactly the same turn-based combat XCOM was) is that you could move through a turn quickly. You could immediately end your turn in both games if people still had moves left but you were satisfied with your position. You could tailor FE:A to move through combat and turns quick, and you could switch to other people in XCOM while a squadmate was still executing his/her turn. It kept the game from being too slow, and I feel like this combat lacks it.It's also not helped by the characters taking strangely wonky path that would sometimes do a near 360 to get to a box when they could just step four paces in a straight line. Also, I despise how the camera would linger on an enemy after you miss, as if to congratulate you on an unlucky dice roll and slow the pace down further.On top of that, the balance was fine right up until I hit the Bulwarks, which I felt were introduced long before I had the capability to deal with them. It kept going on like that from there. Also, like XCOM, the game has a fog of war which the enemies aren't supposed to hit you from until you find each other. Problem is, some of the enemies don't obey that rule, and I'd keep getting hit by ranged units that'd come flying out of the fog of war with (metaphorical) guns blazing even though I hadn't discovered them yet.Also, do you remember how you'd kinda chuckle in XCOM when it'd say you had a 95% chance to hit and you'd still miss like...1 out of every 8-10 shots? Enjoy the most deceptive percentage system in history, where 90% means you're gonna miss 2-3 out of every 5 shots. At one point, out of curiosity, I actually reloaded a save to see how many times I hit an enemy I had an 80% shot of hitting. I got 12 out of 20 before I stopped. Maybe I got unlucky, but that actually feels like a very accurate representation of the accuracy in this game. I understand it's gamblers fallacy to assume 80% means I'll hit four out of five times, but there's a massive difference between that and a near constant 50%. Which leads to the chief complaint about the combat system: its ambiguity. I have to guesstimate how far the enemies are going to move, the percentage system lies to me, caberjacks never seem to be close enough to help anything, and there are the glancing blows that are the RNG's way of saying "you're not appreciating this combat system enough, allow me to screw you over because the unreliable hit percentage wasn't enough." The entire point of strategy and tactics is that a game should do more or less what you tell it, with a little room for surprises. If something goes wrong, it should be because I took a chance and it didn't pay off, and hopefully I'll have enough options to compensate for that. It shouldn't be because the system is so unreliable that I have no idea whether my tactics will work or not. It desperately needs refinement, is what I'm saying.Still, the generations system is awesome, and makes the game worth playing, and for all its frustrations, the combat system has its moments.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is already a pretty complete game, and worth the purchase. The combat is X-Com style, but a good portion of your troops will be melee, so cover is less of a deal. It's mostly about staying outside of the attack range of enemies, and ganging up on them one at a time. (By the end of the game you can sometimes eliminate one enemy per soldier per game though).  The soldier classes are pretty fun, especially the caberjack, which can push and stun enemies. If enemies are stacked in a line, he can even stun more than one. He synergizes well with the alchemist, who can drop some bombs on the enemies he's shoved together. The hunter is a little less impressive, but it's excellent to have one on the team due to the stealth abilities they get from the start. I understand DF is also working adding some hybrid classes.The strategic game has a pretty steep learning curve. Your soldiers will maybe get 4 combats in over the course of their lifetimes, and so you need to build a dynasty. It's a mix of ensuring fertility (many offspring), experience (new soldier experience depends on regent at keep and standards at crucibles), and positive traits (a bit of eugenics between experienced regents and desirable mates). My first couple runs, I couldn't fill out my combat roster on the 5th or so combat.Gripes: later on there are advanced versions of the enemies, which basically just have 2x hp and 2x damage. They don't even color swap them. Learning curve is a bit too steep at the start.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								WAIT FOR THE FINISHED GAME!!!Now that I have that out of the way you may notice how I still recommend it. And that's because I want to emphasize that the game is still fun, just VERY VERY frustrating.The game is very fun and could be very addictive... once they fix the issue of difficulty and others. Think of the game like Xcom if it met with Game of Thrones, with the idea of making families out of heroes that will produce offsprings. On paper this is fantastic and for the most part the execution is more than decent enough when you consider the budget. The mechanics of choosing X or Y is not as punshing as XCom where the latter makes you feel like you just ruined the lives of millions  if you choose one continent over the other. Some complaints I have right now that will make me stop playing the game for now in hopes they'll be addressed:1. Right now how far you get in the game is EXTREMELY dependent on how lucky you are with your initial role of heroes, ages, and classes. For example I just rolled a game where I had like 4 melees and 1 archer. I then made the highest ranked melee into the regent and gave her a partner to produce babies. By the time I built my second keep to get a new regent, I only had one Archer at a decent level, and once I put that one as a regent to give me high level archers I was basically F'ed because I had no other archers for battles, so now I need to fight battles with nothing but melee and alchemists. Which is extremely hard once you hit level 40. So the issue at hand is that the regent/lineage system needs rework. Having to wait 15 years minimum for your next generation of a specific class is horrible. You don't get enough heroes. 2. Heroes don't level up unless you bring them with you to battles and use them to kill enemies. It's fine by itself if you were given higher level heroes, but you tend to be given low level heroes.3. Bulwarks or w/e they're called are broken. So is whatever system that decides how many enemies you gotta fight at a time. I'm in year 40 and I got a map with bulkwarks in groups of 2 and I had to fight like 10 with nothing but melees and one archer. This was a pain, but then like three more appeared. If you're gonna have these guys gain a shield after an attack at least don't make it where damage goes down to 1. Or lower their base damage, because 5-7 per hit is ridiculous.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Just a short review of the game as it's in Early Access December 2014. I've tried two playthroughs by now.  The first went haywire so I restarted, the second I made it to Year 300 (end game). I think there's a bit of a learning curve still :) Anyway, I really, really like the game. It reminds me of a hybrid between XCOM (new one) and The Last Federation. The XCOM part is somewhat simpler in regard to the combat, yet it has its own flavor and you have some pretty clever things you can pull off with the different classes, equipment and skills. As to the Kingdom/Base Management it's two widely different beasts. Where XCOM had a lot of smaller research paths and many types of equipment there are fewer in Massice Chalice, so every choice counts - and smacks - like a b*tch.If I had to pick one great feature of the Kingdom Management it's the breeding for various traits in the regents' children. It makes a heck of a difference. If you marry two regents with bad traits your resulting heroes will be so pathethic it's painful.Right now it's not just playable but also enjoyable. I don't know for sure if there's just a lot more learning to do for me or if there are genuine imbalances in the game. I miss the feeling of late game XCON where you're very powerful and just kill scores of enemies. Actually, the second game I'm not sure I'll actually be able to complete, and I got this nagging feeling that maybe, just maybe, I shouldn't have paired that decent regent with that too young, unknown spouse. Perhaps with the right bloodline with the right traits and personality ...

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Works very well if you're willing to use your imagination in a lot of aspects, and I don't mean that in a bad way. This is a game that wants you to take a second and come up with your own storyline, and if you care about the heroes in your kingdom you'll have a lot more fun than speed running, min-maxing, and generally just treating it like an old SNES game that needs to be beaten than an interactive and deep story/narrative driven epic like it is.Edit: After playing some more, I wanted to make some remarks about the other reviews here. A lot of people complain that the game doesn't really have much in the ways of a tutorial. This creates a really good environment though. In the game, you're new to everything. You're learning what is going just like everyone else, so not knowing the exact stats of a Bulwark but instead getting a narrative description of what it does is actually really satisfying and flavorful.Another point, I've come to really enjoy the breeding. Some people say it isn't predictable, but I can clearly tell which bloodlines are carrying what traits. Yes, some of them will show up more randomly, especially if you have regents with personalities that cause personalities to not be followed, like rebel, but that's honestly how life works. If you have 5 kids, they'll have core beliefs and fringe beliefs and both will make up who they are. For me, a very solid 8/10. Not sure why there are so many negative reviews or why so many people are agreeing with them. I feel like it has to do with how quickly people want to burn through a game on Steam, but this is really a good Double Fine production and it shows with good narrative storytelling and character development.

number of helpful: 6 of 18 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I just finished my first run-through of the game, and I can honsetly say I enjoyed it immensely. A lot of people are jittery about DF having another early access game, but the situation has been made perfectly clear: MASSIVE CHALICE is COMPLETELY FUNDED for the next six months, which is the perfect amount of time to tweak this game to perfection. You may notice a few rough edges and for some people an intimidating learning curve, but the mechanics of this game are solid and have a surprising amount of depth. Like many tactical games, you might build yourself into a corner or find yourself on the wrong end of RNG, but when this game is humming, it's an amazing experience. I can't wait for DF to put the finishing touches on this game and I hope you guys enjoy!Other Misc Facts:-3 base classes currently, hybrid classes planned for future update (which ups the number of options significantly)-Get your highest level characters to be regents: XP is passed on to children of the house. The higher the XP, the higher level your trainee heroes become.-Relics spawn occaisionally when a hero dies. Usually happens when a hero kills a lot of cadence throughout their life. Get these early and keep them in the hands of the fighting members of the family. They level up and turn wimpy heroes into super men/women.-Be smart about movement and sight. Scout ahead with Hunters (using their sneaking ability). Sometimes your sight range is greater than theirs and often it is greater than their movement/attack range. Find the enemy first and utilize crowd control abilities to slow down the enemy (Flarrow blinds enemies for a turn, Knockback can shove enemies into other enemies and can stun each one affected, Prime Target can draw strong opponents away from weak or stranded heroes)Have Fun guys!

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								X-Com meets Rogue Legacy. It's X-Com style combat with the generational traits that Rogue Legacy has. There's a pretty strong emphasis on breeding your bloodlines well to concentrate good traits and training ability as early heroes tend to be pretty mediocre (if not flat out bad). Surprisingly fun. The main thing is that it's hard to grow attached to individual characters as they get rotated out pretty quickly; however the bloodlines seem to often breed a couple of traits 'true' for many generations, giving them a bit of a personality of their own.Combat is fairly simple, but this isn't necessarily a bad thing; I found that I didn't really want to spend hours on a tactical map at a time, since so much of the activity happens strategically. The tactical combat is just enough to be interesting without being too time-consuming, maintaining a quicker pace than e.g. Medieval.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: This is my first game from this developer. I've become aware of a small scandal brewing about this developer's past games, but this review is written with ONLY THIS PARTICULAR GAME in mind. I have no idea what happened with the developer's previous games, and thus that is not the concern of this review.In the time I've spent with this, I've really enjoyed it. It has all the features it claims to in about the way you'd expect them, so if the description looks interesting, you'll probably enjoy it. The game has a fairly simple core mechanic: survive until x year. However, the facets that go into maximizing your chances for survival are many and are quite novel. I really enjoy pairing my strongest fighters and securing even stronger future generations.The music in the game is lovely, and the voice acting is far better than I had anticipated (actually I hadn't anticipated ANY, but the voice acting is really very good). The visual style is a little... art over realism, as it were. But it serves the game well enough that I, as a huge fan of realistic graphics, found myself not caring at all that I wasn't looking at lush forests and TressFX hair. The controls might seem slightly limited at first, but I quickly found they did their job effectively.All in all, this game is great fun and I encourage you to grab it if you're on the fence about it.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												I purchased Massive Chalice after browsing the "Legendary Weapon" trope for a bit on TVTropes. I had not previously heard of the game and was very interested the instant I heard about bloodlines and tactical gameplay. Generational progression of a 300 year war and all that sounded AMAZING, family houses and children and bloodline relics and so on.Then I saw it was by Double Fine, "Wow, those guys are really creative, I generally really like their work!" I thought to myself. The game was funded by Kickstarter too? "Well that's fine, nothing wrong with that, I'm just happy it made it."I purchased the game for the $20 price tag on steam, and loaded it up. I started my new game and... was immediately filled with regret, and it was for one simple reason.No customization.Why, I thought? Was it perhaps just something I had to unlock in game? I decided to google and find out. And the first 3 responses to my search made my interest in the game sink from heavily interested to almost absolutely nothing."There was a kickstarter tier that allowed you to create your own house and that's the reason you can't make your own." Is basically what it boils down to... and from what I have read, there was at one point an interest in including a Create-a-House function in the game post-release, which is fine IMO, but then I read in a more recent post that the idea was scrapped because it wouldn't be fair to backers.Now I have shut the game down and lack enough interest to even bother trying the tutorial. I'm glad I didn't have to wait 2 hours to find this out either, so now I can get my money back. This may seem harsh and all, but I wanted to post this up somewhere and hopefully let someone in the know might be able to bring it up to whom it may concern:' "You lost a sale because I am not allowed to have my own family."I'll even be fair and say: If I could even just make one single custom family for myself to represent my own line, I don't mind if my other 4 families are pre-designed by the backers. But the fact I just plain cannot have my own input in the lore of the game or have some semblance of interaction beyond just being "the player" ... To be blunt: If you don't care about me, why should I care about you?

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								That's a very original and entertaining game, like if X-COM met Game of Thrones for a crossover.People tend to focus on combat, but what's really great about Massive Chalice is the strategy of breeding heroes and trying to have a minimally acceptable team to defend your lands when the Cadence attacks. It can be challenging as you have to plan ahead to have a balance of classes and also take care of the special buildings that give bonus to hero development and research of new 'technologies'.What should you do? Have your best hero available to do battle or marry him with a fertile hero of another family so his offspring have a better chance of being as good (or better!) than himself? Should you appoint your most experienced hero as the standard to be followed by young heroes and risk having only inexperienced youngsters to fight the next invasion? Will they be able to survive without more powerful items and armor? Who will research it?Combat itself is not that original or satisfying at this point, mostly because of balance issues. There are some enemies, especially later in the game, able to single handedly criple or even destroy an average party. Also, there are only 3 classes available. This greatly limits the number of tactics you can use to overcome the battles, and can lead to some repetition during the 300 year timespan of the game.Of course, this is an unfinished product, so we can hope for the combat to get a little better and the planning phase to get more polishment and shine even more.That said, if you like original and challenging games, Massive Chalice's world is surely a good palce for you to play only one more turn.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								¯\_(ツ)_/¯It's an inferior reskin of rage aneurysm in game form X-Com: Enemy Unknown/Within that someone accidentally dumped the Crusader Kings bloodline number crunching into. It's so much like X-Com that it even has the same UI and controls, the same panic level and pick between two battles features, the crap RNG and touchy map movement. All that said, X-Com is an awesome, addicting game, so, I mean, eh, this can't possibly be that bad. I'd wait until it goes live but if you like X-Com and want more of that, this gives you X-Com with a low-fi fantasy skin.At the moment, the classes and mobs do not feel well balanced, with at least one seemingly useless class and a number of monsters that are just no fun to fight, but this will hopefully change before a full release. The gameplay stretches on for years in game but feels more breakneck than X-Com which is supposed to take place over a few months. I didn't find it very enjoyable: I was simultaneously bored by the lack of battles and overwhelmed trying to get a handle on mechanics, stats, traits and personalities before my soldiers died. Also had a lot of trouble actually keeping my ranks up; at one point I had 6 Hunters and that was it.Also, this is just petty, but I really liked the idea of their art direction but it didn't seem well executed in game; it felt unfinished. When I started my first forest map battle, my first thought was, "Wow, they slapped some really low res textures onto the tree meshes from X-Com didn't they?"

												Amazing game. Does amazing things within the tactical RPG genre, and is just soooooo fun to play.But..it requires patience with your intuitions and personal playstyle, which could simply just not work in a long-term strategy game like this. Be willing to start over if you have to. And for God's sake be CAREFUL with those random events. I would recommend that if ANY (and I mean ANY) random event occurs, you IMMEDIATELY check the Wiki for what could occur given the choice you make within the event.Why? Because while I really and truly love EVERYTHING this game does as a tactical RPG (and yes I've played the XCOMs, I still prefer this game), the events are not just like "aw, that sucks, but whatevs."Instead, they're like "Wait...what??....but I'm almost there! NO. SCREW THIS. IM STARTING OVER/NEVER PLAYING AGAIN." Events can be brutal and screw up your long term plans, which you worked suuuuper hard for. And that just feels poopy.But seriously, other than that (and the annoyance that just comes from random chance) this game is amazing and you should give it a fair shake, especially if its on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you took you standard turn-based strategy game like X-Com, added a little bit of the Sims and Pokemon breeding, and sprinkle on the sass and humor of Double Fine all over it, you get something close, yet at the same time nothing near what Massive Chalice is. A definite evolutionary experiment for the genre that can end up being revolutionary or a downright disaster. You might wanna take some notes, eugenics is involved.Gameplay: 92/100 A-Massive Chalice plays like any other turn based strategy game at first, moving your units into positions which offer a greater tactical advantage, setting up a trap, or pulling off a successful raid. While the combat mechanics are all familiar, moving, using skills, on and on, that is about as similar Massive Chalice is to other games of the like, specifically X-Com: Enemy Unknown, since it's one of the more recent successes of the genre. The rest of the gameplay isn't even on the battlefield, but in your kingdoms, putting units together in partnerships from the multitudes of clans, breeding them to produce offspring who will pass down traits to help improve your army as time goes by, some will die of old age, others in battle, some at random, some not so random - the list just goes on and on and you have to decide which way you want things to go, all the while fending off this nebulous invading force. Essentially, Massive Chalice takes away the random chance with the units and puts it in the players trusting hands, making everyone your responsibility. Good luck!Audio: 90/100 A-Being an Early Access game, things are bound to change, and the music isn't exempt from this. That said, the music that is currently in the game is well made and fits the atmosphere of the game and environments. This goes for the sound effects as well, since some sound like placeholders for better samples, others feel well polished and ready to go into your ears. The voice acting is done fairly well, too. The two main voices coming from the Massive Chalice itself, features a male being and a female being, both two different personalities that bicker and support you all at once or at each other. At times they are hilarious, while other times they can be a bit of a downer as you're trying to turn the tide of the war and one pipes up and says "Their numbers are endless and instantly replaced, we must grow into maturity..." or something like that.Visuals: 95/100 AThis is something that has caused some discussion within the community, both positive and negative, while Double Fine has never been known for its realism, especially visually, some complaints have been that the visuals are too simplified, but this is my review, not theirs, and I respectfully disagree. Now, I will agree that the graphics are simple, harkening back to the early PC days of Another World or Alone in the Dark, and more recently Minecraft, I don't think that they are too simple for the genre, you have to remember that graphics are part wow-factor and part world building, and if one fails in its mission, then the graphics mean nothing in the end. With that in mind, the style of the characters, the landscapes, the flow of water, the weapons used, they all fit into this world. It's not perfect, again - early access game still, but it has a firm style of what it wants to look like and sway this way or that.  Content: 97/100 A+I touched on some of the things you need to juggle in Massive Chalice outside of combat alone. I found myself spending a fair amount of time deciding which members of my team should be taken out so that they can go and get freaky with one another to make me more soldiers. And then you have to build castles and other structures if you want to advance certain technologies or unlock other classes of fighters, fixing disputes with your citizens, and then deciding which battle to engage in when that time comes. Oh - and did I mention the whole game is essentially on a giant time limit? Yeah, the clock, another thing to fight. You will be spending a lot of time tweaking and tinkering with everything in this game and you won't have much choice because as time goes by, your current fighters get older and will die. Lots of people will die. You won't have that one badass from day one who kills everything, but you may be able to pass down trinkets and whatnots that hold special abilities and stats that can be passed down from generation unto generation. Story: 86/100 B+There is a story, believe it or not, but as I played, it felt like it took a backseat to the gameplay. It's still there, but it wasn't interweaved into the gameplay as other games, it gets mentioned here and there, but the fights seems a bit disconnected to the rest of the situations happening. But maybe this is something that'll get hammered out at a later time as the core gameplay is worked out and balanced, which isn't a bad strategy at all. What story there is, is constructed decently, so it's hard to make a judgement on something that isn't finalized.Design: 88/100 B+From a purely mechanical standpoint, Massive Chalice is a massive undertaking that works for the most part. The ideas are there, they're original for the genre, and they add many layers of replayability to the game outside of a dice roll. The battlefields are laid out in creative ways, offering plenty of opportunity to form a strategy. The variety is also a welcome sight, from the characters, to the enemies, and the landscape itself, which you can use to your advantage as well, not just by hiding behind, but offensively.Performance: 86/100 B+I had to play this at a lower to mid-range settings on my current computer where the game ran the smoothest and looked the best. While there are a fair amount of options to tinker with, the game seems to run at a slightly slower pace, especially in battle, but I have to reiterate this - Early Access. There's still a bunch of work to be done at almost every angle, optimizing code and programming and who knows what else. There is some clipping here and there, but nothing as notorious as the "I can't shoot through walls, but lemme take a shot through a building" glitch from X-Com: Enemy Unknown. Failed psychic school my♥♥♥♥♥Verdict: 90/100 A-Massive Chalice is a massive risk, but with all that risk comes potential. It's nice to see a company actually attempt something with this much ambition and still try to make it the best they can. There are issues, of course, but these are more growing pains than pure stupidity. Do I recommend? Yes.

Time for playthrough: Took 13.7 hrs to finish game on normal (incl tutorial) without any saving/reloading. I assume if you play with mouse instead of gamepad it's down to 12 hours.Game-play: You are mostly managing your heroes as resources and try to breed (!) better heroes - the bloodline system works and is fun, though it's not worth going into the details too much, as few heroes will have more than 2 fights in them before they die of old age and get replaced by younger ones. content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												I loved this game, and consider it a hidden gem. It plays like X-COM, with a mating/genetics system like Fire Emblem (in perpetuiity), and a unique and charming aesthetic/world. You have a squad of soldiers who revolve throughut the game as they are born, mature, and die, each with distinguishable characteristics. This gives them flair and make it even more heartbreaking when they die because you missed the shot THAT IT SAID HAD A 90% CHANCE OF LANDING, HOW COULD IT HAVE MISSED?!On the downside, the campaign is small and feels repetitive. There's not a lot of customizable bells and whistles so you've pretty much seen it all after you get 20% in. While this is a drag, keep in mind that it is a medium-sized game. It acomplishes what it sets out to do, and while it lacks a full-feature-game feel, it also lacks the cost. Keeping in mind the price tag, I would label it a must-play.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												If you have ever played XCOM: Enemy Unknown, or XCOM 2, and you enjoy fantasy settings with a grand sense of adventure, you will like Smaller Cup- I mean MASSIVE CHALICE. I have less than an hour into the game, but I can tell you it flows almost identically to modern XCOM. The game appears to have less pressure on the player than XCOM from the get go, but I could see how that could easily change. Much like the way that countries all start support the XCOM project, you can readily have regions in MC be over taken by you enemy. I can't tell you what happens when that occurs, but the game starts out with a given time limit that you have to ensure your survival for, or else the game will end. The tacical, turn based combat does not use cover or facing unfortunately. Vangaurds start as low leveled fighters and, unlike XCOM, can be turned into research personelle, or kings and queens that run your other supported regions. Thus making a new, and interesting strain on your troops available for combat. You will probably loose if you throw all your Vanguards into R&D, royality, or just into fighting. Like XCOM, MC forces you to make choices about who to train, what to research when, and prioritise your limited resources. Unlike XCOM it has a wonderful air of not taking it's self too seriously. The little bits of humor thrown in are perfect and over all make you feel not as bad about making poor choices in the game. This is further supported by a semi-cartoonish art style which show cases vibrant colors and original character designs beautifully. MASSIVE CHALICE is a pretty damn good game that I'd recommend to anyone looking for something as fun as XCOM, or other turn based strategy games, and likes a bit of humor.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Massive Chalice or Eugenics War (what it feels like to me at least) is a turn-based strategy game. It also has a kingdom management aspect to it but for the most part it is a turn-based tactical combat game.Eugenics War (Massive Chalice) is built around a hero breeding system. Every single marriage is your decision. Your choices can create a bloodline full of hearty and quick heroes or asthmatic and slow ones. With every choice having positive and negative consequences you’ll have to weigh every decision.Combat is grid and turn based. If you’ve played Final Fantasy Tactics or XCOM you know what to expect. Though don’t expect the same amount of variety of units as Final Fantasy Tactics or the complexity of XCOM. This is a lighter squad based game.Is this game for everyone? Of course not, the game gets a little repetitive and a lot of the unique ideas in this title are not fully realized. It is however a very interesting game that does something different from most turn based (and squad based) strategy games.As with most games on Steam if you don’t feel like taking a risk on this at full price just wait for a sale; I purchased my copy in a bundle and only ended up paying $1.25. At that price I feel I definitely got my money’s worth, had I paid full price I would still be satisfied though.

												A very fun game that can be very unforgiving. The way legacy and heros work is unique and makes the game very nice.I would suggest keeping the Keeps for Breeding close and the Cruicbels and Research Stations at the outer edges. Reason is that You can survive without increased speed in research in the end game, and the crucibels only ensure your new heros start at a better level. But without new heros you will lose the game. content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Just beat massive challice, and... I loved it. I was super into x-com, so I saw this on sale and gave it a shot.It's not quite as fleshed out as x-com, the game feels a bit bare-bones, but the there are a lot of really interesting mehcanics that aren't immediately obvious. For example, there are only 3 classes, but by marring together heros from 2 different classes, you can create mixes. The regent determines the weapon and armor, and their partner determines they're sub-class, so there are actually 9 different classes. Also, the hero-breeding is really deep, heros have actual genes. So some genese aren't expressed, but can still show if you marry them with somebody else that also has the dormant gene.The music is super catchy, that's always a huge plus. The combat is similar to x-com, in that it heavily rewards taking it slow, and picking off straglers until there's nobody left.I DEFINETLY recommend playing on Ironman mode, even if you have to lower the difficulty. X-com is way more fun when played like a roguelike, and this game is too.I played on ironman normal mode, and I found it to be slightly too easy, but pretty close to perfect. I got my self in a few tight spots, but I got through the game on my first try. Definetly put it on hard if you're not playing ironman mode.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												Massive Chalice is a good example of a game that went through the Early Access phase and was eventually followed through to successful completion.  I've seen several games that went through Early Access and were later abandoned by the developer, so it's nice to see an example that turned out to be a polished and fun game.You'll see a lot of people commenting about how the play style is similar to Xcom, and they're right.  I do like Xcom, but I actually like Massive Chalice better than Xcom because of the way heros can be married together to form families and offspring, and eventually new heroes.  The traits and stats of the parents influence the traits, stats, and initial experience level of the next generation of heroes.  With some clever planning over which hero I marry to another, I can have a batch of fresh new recruits leveled up and waiting to replace the aging (or dead) ones.  Contrast that with Xcom, where you lose one of your soldiers and they're just gone.I feel like Massive Chalice's building placement mechanic improved on the 'base building' mechanic seen in Xcom.  I don't have to worry about excavating some area, and providing power or anything silly like that.  Instead they added bonuses based on what building you place and where.  They simplified the building concept while also improving on it.  I also like the random events that come up and require a decision to be made.  The decisions made for those events have lasting effects on how the game progresses, and add flavor to the story.I hope the developers consider making a Massive Chalice 2.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												I was prepared for the same disappointment with Massive Chalice as I was with Spacebase DF-9. Long story short, people paid money and the Double Fine gave up on making the game, leaving everyone with a game that essentially never left alpha. But funnily enough, that wasn’t the case. Massive Chalice is essentially XCOM cross the map from the Game of Thrones introduction.The enemies are varied and you can use their corpses ro craft new weapons, items and armor. Someone dies and there’s no getting back up again. Every mission is very simple: Kill all the Cadence monsters. With no variance, the game can be a little repetitive at times. But I don’t enjoy this game for the combat.Almost unheard of, but one of the best parts about this game is the micro-managing between battles. And here’s where the Game of Thrones comes into it. You have several families/clans under your control which you place into keeps around your kingdom. Each clan has a dominant class and by intermingling different clans, you can produce hybrid classes and place emphasis on certain traits. You are an immortal dictator with complete oversight of your kingdom, the oversight and totalitarian control needed to save the realm.I have picked up some issues. The classes are really, really unintuitive. An alchemist has a giant claw and throws flasks, a hunter has a crossbow and a caber just bashes the♥♥♥♥♥♥out enemies with a caber (log of wood used in the Scottish sport Caber Tossing). The hybrid classes are even more confusing with names like Blastcapper, Enforcer and Boomstriker (lucky guess as to what hybrids they are).Asides from this, still a good game. It has a simple eloquence to it which Double Fine have always had a knack for. Even though your heroes die of old age, the next generation start at a higher level, meaning that you feel like you’re progressing despite losing your best warriors to the ravages of time. Double-Fine have made some game design choices which are great. Knowing about the game before I started, I expected heaps of flaws. But somehow Double-Fine have managed to find ways around it.For full review, visit: http://icarusreviews.net/2015/08/23/massive-chalice/

												Let's start with the bad. This game has so much wasted potential that I could basically cry. But that is typical of a Massive Chalice's release. The strategy/ruling part is fun enough to keep you busy for a while choosing regents, partners, researches and building stuff and the combat part is also fun enough (even though a total rip-off from X-Com). number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Pros:Solid and enjoyable gameplayentertaining soundbitesoriginal conceptCons:I don't like the art style (but that's personal preference)doesn't feel like it will have a high replayabilityI only recently picked up this game while it was on sale and I must say I wish I had bought it sooner. Massive Chalice is an excellent blend of long term strategy and turn based tactics. to give you a comparison, it plays very much like a low fantasy version of XCOM Enemy Unknown. You take on the role of the faceless (and mute) commander, You place your buildings into your lands. The enemy attacks several provinces at once and you can only defenc one of them.But unlike XCOM, your heros have a limited lifespan and will eventually die of age if the enemy doesn't get them first.to save some of their valuable traits you can marry your heros off in order to breed the next generation of cannon fodder. This adds a whole new dimension to strategy and it is something I wish more games could implement.overall I would give it about a 4/5the only downsides are the blocky looking art style which I don't like but seems popular these days. and the fact that it seems like it will have limited replayability, there are only so many ways to do things so I feel that aside from achivement hunting it won't get to many repeats from me.

												This game is challenging.这个游戏很有挑战性。For my first try I think it is an XCOM like game.我刚开始的时候以为这又是一个仿幽浮系列的游戏。But after that I realized I`m wrong about the concepts of this game.之后，我才明白自己想错了。It does like XCOM, BattleBrothers or whatever turn based stragety game, but there is a differences, you are not chose your warrior but your bloodlines. You need to make your attention on your population which directly affects the heros you can choose in a single battle, also the age of your heros does have the same effects.这确实像幽浮、兄弟战团或者其他的什么回合制策略类游戏，不过这里有些不一样的地方，你不是选择你的战士，而是选择你的血统。你需要时刻注意你的人口信息，它直接影响到你每场能选择的英雄数目，当然，还有年龄。There are actually 12 types of units rather than the simple 3. Try not to be agressive before you find out the attribute of those invadors.这游戏还有各种各样的怪物。在弄清楚它们的特性之前，切忌冒进。GL HF.祝你好运，玩得愉快！

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												I loved this game especially how you have to keep bloodlines going and keep your people alive. I also liked how the combat was done. It is pretty solid in how they made it. Some great points like it states on the games store page.Bloodline Genetics - MASSIVE CHALICE features an innovative Bloodline system that allows the player to marry heroes together to produce children. The Bloodline system uses a randomized genetic code for every hero. Their children can end up with the best (or worst!) gameplay-impacting traits of their parents. Permadeath - The heroes in MASSIVE CHALICE age over the course of the timeline and eventually pass away. This forces the player to engage in the beauty of permadeath and always juggle an imperfect party of heroes with which to do battle! Long View Strategy - Because the war lasts 300 years, players need to take a long view of their strategy. Decisions have to be made dozens of years in advance and long-term planning is incredibly important. That 3-year-old toddler is going to grow up to be your most reliable melee fighter sooner than you think!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												A decent game overall. I guess I am lucky that I didn't play xcom before because it seems to amplify the hate for this game. I found it quite hard and frustrating the first time I played. After 2-3 hours of rage quits I started to actually use the skills of the characters and to pay attention to the genetics of the houses, then I finished it in about 10-11 hours. It is really fun to play on normal difficulty and not as tedious or impossible as some suggested.The game has some interesting mechanics, I have played Civ5 and Civ4 and I found the battle system to be similar, but the game really shines when you have to take care of you Nation. The system based on noble houses that have to mate with one another to produce offspring suitable for combat, rule or study is really nice. I am sure this game did not live up to the hype as many players say, but it is definitely not bad or shallow. As heroes evolve, so do the enemies and the tactical battles get more and more interesting.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												I was intrigued by this game, but didn't think I would be really into it at, and just tried it to see. Well now I know I really like it! The game reminds me of the HOMM games, with many differences of course.My first playthrough, I played without paying much attention and dropped it after about 50 years, I was doomed...I cleared the game with my 2nd playthrough, and I still did so many bad things in it... (normal difficulty).Pros:- Interesting bloodline thematic, I don't remember having that in another game. It was nice though I wish I knew earlier than once you place a bloodline in a keep you're stuck with them forever.- The mini question games that popped up every now and then, that was amusing and quick, I kept waiting for a new one to pop.- The voice actors are great!- I liked the only one mission for the whole game thing, so if you mess up, you got to restart from scratch, it's quite refreshing (though I probably wouldn't feel that way if I failed around year 280 ;) )- Following above, being strong at one point doesn't mean that you'll stay this way, things happen and if you don't pay attention you're back to having weak heroes again. - The mixing of classes to create new classes was fun!- The various attributes for a heroes and the random traits and personalities.- Various details like a feud can occur between families, which will decrease their efficiency if together in battle.- Since the game is randomized the replay value is pretty good.Neutral:- Somehow I wasn't a huge fan of the battles, and skipped the one before the last since I could afford it,- I got a bit annoyed at having so many sages dying in a row, till I figured out making young ones sage would bypass this issue :)Cons:- The voices get old quickly as they keep repeating the same stuff over and over again... I understand the game is randomized so they cannot have fresh voices for everything, but more variety would have been nice.- There's pretty much no story told, all we know is that there's an evil corrupting the land and it will take 300 years for the chalice to be able to clean it up... strong storytelling!- Not enough upgrades in the end: I used mostly hunters and had plenty of heroes all around, so around 200 years I maxed out all I care for and ended up doing the heroes and alchemist upgrades just because I had to do something... I wish I would have looked forward to upgrades during the whole game. (it's not a big issue of course).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Very interesting and very charming turn based strategy game. If you like the genre then I absolutely recommend you give this a shot!-----+Interesting macro management.+Varied enemies that encourage the use of different tactics to defeat.+Pleasant art style and animations.+Nice sound direction, both in music and sound effects.+Lots of quirky humour.+Plays well with a controller.+/- Macro Management can be a bit chaotic and unclear what's actually happening under the hood.-Only three weapon styles. (Though abiities can vary and they each compliment each other well.)-After the initial learning curve, maybe a tad on the easier side. (If so, crank up the difficulty!)-Potential for end game tedium through the final quarter of a campaign. (Though personally it kept me quite engaged.)-----I wasn't expecting to enjoy MASSIVE CHALICE as much as I have done thus far. I suppose it is similar in a lot of ways to the recent X-COM games in that the game requires you to succeed at both managing a base and also managing the strategic battles, and like X-COM if you fail at either element too badly you stand a good chance of losing the game.The "Base" component of MASSIVE CHALICE places you as the immortal leader of a small kingdom that spans several hundred years over the course of the game. You're expected to manage the continual repopulation of your roster of heroes as they die to old age through a Game Of Thrones-ey family system where you build keeps and assign lords and ladies to have lots of heroic children. These children may inherit some of the personality quirks or physical traits of their parents as well as experience points or even family heirloom weapons. This ensures that over the course of the game you can maintain a sense of growth in your hero roster as the game progresses through the family ties.You can also spend time researching new weapons, armours and items for use in the field and the game occasionally throws up points of contention amongst the populace for you to make decisions on which will have either positive or negative effects, similar to what you may have seen in The Banner Saga.The battles themselves present you with a variety of legitimate threats that I'd rather not spoil for you that escalate as time progresses. Enemies are interesting in that the threats they pose are often not necessarily tied in to their raw power in terms of health pools and damage they can deal. Encountering them in unexpected combinations can make for some interesting tactical puzzles and this is doubly true with the nature of your ever changing roster of heroes. You may not have a full set of tools available for you to tackle these problems with depending on how the baby-making situation goes.I've got a fair amount of experience with games in this genre and for me this game was refreshingly different and thoroughly enjoyable.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												I was initially underwhelmed, but really glad I stuck with it and finished. It's a light, fresh, intriguing take on the X-Com formula. They tried for something really different and didn't entirely succeed (the biggest shortcoming is that the interface isn't quite able to handle the game's complexity), but that's an expected outcome for such an experiment. Ultimately though, it's a very innovative and aesthetically pleasing game, and I hope future games are able to run with some of the ideas that are explored here.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Massive Chalice or Eugenics War (what it feels like to me at least) is a turn-based strategy game. It also has a kingdom management aspect to it but for the most part it is a turn-based tactical combat game.Eugenics War (Massive Chalice) is built around a hero breeding system. Every single marriage is your decision. Your choices can create a bloodline full of hearty and quick heroes or asthmatic and slow ones. With every choice having positive and negative consequences you’ll have to weigh every decision.Combat is grid and turn based. If you’ve played Final Fantasy Tactics or XCOM you know what to expect. Though don’t expect the same amount of variety of units as Final Fantasy Tactics or the complexity of XCOM. This is a lighter squad based game.Is this game for everyone? Of course not, the game gets a little repetitive and a lot of the unique ideas in this title are not fully realized. It is however a very interesting game that does something different from most turn based (and squad based) strategy games.As with most games on Steam if you don’t feel like taking a risk on this at full price just wait for a sale; I purchased my copy in a bundle and only ended up paying $1.25. At that price I feel I definitely got my money’s worth, had I paid full price I would still be satisfied though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												I loved this game, and consider it a hidden gem. It plays like X-COM, with a mating/genetics system like Fire Emblem (in perpetuiity), and a unique and charming aesthetic/world. You have a squad of soldiers who revolve throughut the game as they are born, mature, and die, each with distinguishable characteristics. This gives them flair and make it even more heartbreaking when they die because you missed the shot THAT IT SAID HAD A 90% CHANCE OF LANDING, HOW COULD IT HAVE MISSED?!On the downside, the campaign is small and feels repetitive. There's not a lot of customizable bells and whistles so you've pretty much seen it all after you get 20% in. While this is a drag, keep in mind that it is a medium-sized game. It acomplishes what it sets out to do, and while it lacks a full-feature-game feel, it also lacks the cost. Keeping in mind the price tag, I would label it a must-play.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Massive Chalice is another super solid indie game from DoubleFine Productions. Basically take XCOM's line of sight concept, tone it down in complexity, add a super interesting base building / heredity simulation game and then you have Massive Chalice. Extremely fun game, and the first play through is an absolute blast. Guaranteed for an easy 20 - 30 hours of greatness. 10/10 for the initial playthrough, then moves down to a 9/10 or 8/10 on consecutive playthroughs due to the top-down rpg growing somewhat stale because of a slight lack of depth.

												I'm a fan of turn based games and I personally like this a lot more than XCOM. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												Good concept, execution is sadly lacking.It's essentially a really basic X-COM/Banner Saga type of turn-based tactical combat, except you never get attached to your characters because the game kills them off from old-age after about 2 battles, only to be replaced by different characters who will also die at age 65 after 2 battles. Rinse and repeat. In between combat encounters you get to take very few decisions regarding your kingdom, the improvements you wish to prioritize and the characters you wish to assign to various functions(lord of the keep, researcher, trainer, etc.) . Once characters are assigned to a function they are no longer eligible for combat and you get in fact little to no interaction with them, making them little more than stats on a spreadsheet. They will also die of old age before you even memorize their names. Rinse and repeat.The artistic direction is interesting but the game's graphics don't live up to it. There are also disparities in the way some units or objects look when compared to others, and the game just ends up looking weird and sometimes ugly.The repetitive nature of Massive Chalice would not be a big issue if the core gameplay would not feel so formulaic. But when you are not given any interesting gameplay mechanics to play with, or any reason to care about what you're doing, why would you continue playing?

Posted: November 8, 2016
												A decent game overall. I guess I am lucky that I didn't play xcom before because it seems to amplify the hate for this game. I found it quite hard and frustrating the first time I played. After 2-3 hours of rage quits I started to actually use the skills of the characters and to pay attention to the genetics of the houses, then I finished it in about 10-11 hours. It is really fun to play on normal difficulty and not as tedious or impossible as some suggested.The game has some interesting mechanics, I have played Civ5 and Civ4 and I found the battle system to be similar, but the game really shines when you have to take care of you Nation. The system based on noble houses that have to mate with one another to produce offspring suitable for combat, rule or study is really nice. I am sure this game did not live up to the hype as many players say, but it is definitely not bad or shallow. As heroes evolve, so do the enemies and the tactical battles get more and more interesting.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Scratches the tactical game itch. Having the game take place over a period of 300 years and having the player essentially breed their army over several generations was an interesting way to handle resource management inbetween combat encounters instead of just using the XCOM-style base management.There may be some balance issues between the unit classes you have, and some may not like having most of the classes be permutations on three main classes, but it didn't get repetitive over my playthrough. Massive Chalice may not be a great game for repeated playthroughs, but it was fantastic for a one-off. I love eet.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												It is  tactical battle and a unique game of strategy. It was good but could have been much better. The strategy seciotn was primarily breeding your next generation of warriors and scholars using sires which were imperfect. You had to decide which defects to live with. The list of characteristics was relatively few and it was often hard to tell how choices affected the outcome in battle.  For instance, I never could tell what effect "drrunk" had on performance.  Another frustrating thing about the stategy section was the random events which were relatively few in number and the best answer wasn't logical - just random.  It would have been much better if all actions had positive and negative consequences which had to be weighed without knowing the severity of the impact.  The tactical game was good.  I recently went back to play xcom, but the tactical battles were clunky and the time  limitation frustrating. In this game, you always knew how far you could move and still attack. The management was smooth.  One unfortunate thing was that distance made very little impact on accuracy of archers - it was mostly warrier level and skill rating. It was also hard to tell when you were lined up with enemies to hit multiple with one shoot.  I would have to wait several years before enjoying a replay.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												I loved this game, and consider it a hidden gem. It plays like X-COM, with a mating/genetics system like Fire Emblem (in perpetuiity), and a unique and charming aesthetic/world. You have a squad of soldiers who revolve throughut the game as they are born, mature, and die, each with distinguishable characteristics. This gives them flair and make it even more heartbreaking when they die because you missed the shot THAT IT SAID HAD A 90% CHANCE OF LANDING, HOW COULD IT HAVE MISSED?!On the downside, the campaign is small and feels repetitive. There's not a lot of customizable bells and whistles so you've pretty much seen it all after you get 20% in. While this is a drag, keep in mind that it is a medium-sized game. It acomplishes what it sets out to do, and while it lacks a full-feature-game feel, it also lacks the cost. Keeping in mind the price tag, I would label it a must-play.

												This game is challenging.这个游戏很有挑战性。For my first try I think it is an XCOM like game.我刚开始的时候以为这又是一个仿幽浮系列的游戏。But after that I realized I`m wrong about the concepts of this game.之后，我才明白自己想错了。It does like XCOM, BattleBrothers or whatever turn based stragety game, but there is a differences, you are not chose your warrior but your bloodlines. You need to make your attention on your population which directly affects the heros you can choose in a single battle, also the age of your heros does have the same effects.这确实像幽浮、兄弟战团或者其他的什么回合制策略类游戏，不过这里有些不一样的地方，你不是选择你的战士，而是选择你的血统。你需要时刻注意你的人口信息，它直接影响到你每场能选择的英雄数目，当然，还有年龄。There are actually 12 types of units rather than the simple 3. And each type is unique. In the right usage of your abilities that you can make it easy to defeat your enemies. i.e. Due to the lack management of population I use only to Shadowjacker to fight a battle, but I won(In a stealth->recon->stun->attack process). So there is a lot much fun.这里不单单是3种单位，实际是12种单位。每一个单位都是很特别的。使用正确就能轻易击败你的敌人。举个栗子，由于我对人口管理的疏漏，我有一场战斗只有2个潜影破坏者，但是，我通过潜行-〉侦查-〉击晕-〉攻击的流程赢了那局。所以我玩这游戏不会少乐子And there are different types of monsters. Try not to be agressive before you find out the attribute of those invadors.这游戏还有各种各样的怪物。在弄清楚它们的特性之前，切忌冒进。GL HF.祝你好运，玩得愉快！

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Pros:Solid and enjoyable gameplayentertaining soundbitesoriginal conceptCons:I don't like the art style (but that's personal preference)doesn't feel like it will have a high replayabilityI only recently picked up this game while it was on sale and I must say I wish I had bought it sooner. Massive Chalice is an excellent blend of long term strategy and turn based tactics. to give you a comparison, it plays very much like a low fantasy version of XCOM Enemy Unknown. You take on the role of the faceless (and mute) commander, You place your buildings into your lands. The enemy attacks several provinces at once and you can only defenc one of them.But unlike XCOM, your heros have a limited lifespan and will eventually die of age if the enemy doesn't get them first.to save some of their valuable traits you can marry your heros off in order to breed the next generation of cannon fodder. This adds a whole new dimension to strategy and it is something I wish more games could implement.overall I would give it about a 4/5the only downsides are the blocky looking art style which I don't like but seems popular these days. and the fact that it seems like it will have limited replayability, there are only so many ways to do things so I feel that aside from achivement hunting it won't get to many repeats from me.

												(7/10) This game has more than meets the eye. I don't like the art style (the character models are hideous) but the breeding of your heroes is fascinating. Unfortunately, the game doesn't prepare you for the final battle so the way you build your bloodlines matters a lot. I did't mind figuring it our but this game is hard if you don't know what you are doing and hard if you do. Good strategy helps but there is lots of randomness which leaves replay-ability but sometimes had me tearing my hair out. Ending was anticlimactic. I guess I was just expecting more celebration after 300 years of toil.  Maybe a list of my heroes or them all at a dance afterwards. But Massive Chalice is worth the price I paid and I recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Just beat massive challice, and... I loved it. I was super into x-com, so I saw this on sale and gave it a shot.It's not quite as fleshed out as x-com, the game feels a bit bare-bones, but the there are a lot of really interesting mehcanics that aren't immediately obvious. For example, there are only 3 classes, but by marring together heros from 2 different classes, you can create mixes. The regent determines the weapon and armor, and their partner determines they're sub-class, so there are actually 9 different classes. Also, the hero-breeding is really deep, heros have actual genes. So some genese aren't expressed, but can still show if you marry them with somebody else that also has the dormant gene.The music is super catchy, that's always a huge plus. The combat is similar to x-com, in that it heavily rewards taking it slow, and picking off straglers until there's nobody left.I DEFINETLY recommend playing on Ironman mode, even if you have to lower the difficulty. X-com is way more fun when played like a roguelike, and this game is too.I played on ironman normal mode, and I found it to be slightly too easy, but pretty close to perfect. I got my self in a few tight spots, but I got through the game on my first try. Definetly put it on hard if you're not playing ironman mode.

Posted: January 13, 2016
												Let's start with the bad. This game has so much wasted potential that I could basically cry. But that is typical of a Massive Chalice's release. The strategy/ruling part is fun enough to keep you busy for a while choosing regents, partners, researches and building stuff and the combat part is also fun enough (even though a total rip-off from X-Com). The problem is, even though the game's finished it looks unfinished. The zen graphic they adopted make everything look bland and forgettable, not to mention the combat locations, after the first combat you neither distinguish, nor you care where you are fighting. I played the game on Hard difficulty and it wasn't difficult to finish and as a reward I got what? A long list of credits. Yeah, you heard right, instead of complicated statistics or charts to display my 300 years prowess, I got nothing. DoubleFine can't be trusted, they are at the opposite end of the spectrum where Overkill is (still supporting Payday 2 after years). Can't really reccomened the game for 20€ though, its worth is more in the 5€ price range I'd say.+ Fun Game and Good Ideas+ Interesting Story- Looks Unfinished- Bland Graphics- No Post-Game Statistics7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												I was prepared for the same disappointment with Massive Chalice as I was with Spacebase DF-9. Long story short, people paid money and the Double Fine gave up on making the game, leaving everyone with a game that essentially never left alpha. But funnily enough, that wasn’t the case. Massive Chalice is essentially XCOM cross the map from the Game of Thrones introduction.The enemies are varied and you can use their corpses ro craft new weapons, items and armor. Someone dies and there’s no getting back up again. Every mission is very simple: Kill all the Cadence monsters. With no variance, the game can be a little repetitive at times. But I don’t enjoy this game for the combat.Almost unheard of, but one of the best parts about this game is the micro-managing between battles. And here’s where the Game of Thrones comes into it. You have several families/clans under your control which you place into keeps around your kingdom. Each clan has a dominant class and by intermingling different clans, you can produce hybrid classes and place emphasis on certain traits. You are an immortal dictator with complete oversight of your kingdom, the oversight and totalitarian control needed to save the realm.I have picked up some issues. The classes are really, really unintuitive. An alchemist has a giant claw and throws flasks, a hunter has a crossbow and a caber just bashes the♥♥♥♥♥♥out enemies with a caber (log of wood used in the Scottish sport Caber Tossing). The hybrid classes are even more confusing with names like Blastcapper, Enforcer and Boomstriker (lucky guess as to what hybrids they are).Asides from this, still a good game. It has a simple eloquence to it which Double Fine have always had a knack for. Even though your heroes die of old age, the next generation start at a higher level, meaning that you feel like you’re progressing despite losing your best warriors to the ravages of time. Double-Fine have made some game design choices which are great. Knowing about the game before I started, I expected heaps of flaws. But somehow Double-Fine have managed to find ways around it.For full review, visit: http://icarusreviews.net/2015/08/23/massive-chalice/

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												Good concept, execution is sadly lacking.It's essentially a really basic X-COM/Banner Saga type of turn-based tactical combat, except you never get attached to your characters because the game kills them off from old-age after about 2 battles, only to be replaced by different characters who will also die at age 65 after 2 battles. Rinse and repeat. In between combat encounters you get to take very few decisions regarding your kingdom, the improvements you wish to prioritize and the characters you wish to assign to various functions(lord of the keep, researcher, trainer, etc.) . Once characters are assigned to a function they are no longer eligible for combat and you get in fact little to no interaction with them, making them little more than stats on a spreadsheet. They will also die of old age before you even memorize their names. Rinse and repeat.The artistic direction is interesting but the game's graphics don't live up to it. There are also disparities in the way some units or objects look when compared to others, and the game just ends up looking weird and sometimes ugly.The repetitive nature of Massive Chalice would not be a big issue if the core gameplay would not feel so formulaic. But when you are not given any interesting gameplay mechanics to play with, or any reason to care about what you're doing, why would you continue playing?

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												I loved this game especially how you have to keep bloodlines going and keep your people alive. I also liked how the combat was done. It is pretty solid in how they made it. Some great points like it states on the games store page.Bloodline Genetics - MASSIVE CHALICE features an innovative Bloodline system that allows the player to marry heroes together to produce children. The Bloodline system uses a randomized genetic code for every hero. Their children can end up with the best (or worst!) gameplay-impacting traits of their parents. Permadeath - The heroes in MASSIVE CHALICE age over the course of the timeline and eventually pass away. This forces the player to engage in the beauty of permadeath and always juggle an imperfect party of heroes with which to do battle! Long View Strategy - Because the war lasts 300 years, players need to take a long view of their strategy. Decisions have to be made dozens of years in advance and long-term planning is incredibly important. That 3-year-old toddler is going to grow up to be your most reliable melee fighter sooner than you think!

Posted: December 24, 2015
												I was initially apprehensive in getting this game because I was burnt by Spacebase DF9 (a failed Early Access title by Double Fine), but I really liked the idea of what Massive Chalice was about, and there was always the option of Steam refunds now.Boy, was I glad I took a chance! This game is surprisingly thoughtful - and painful. Your heroes will die all the time, but if you are a fan of XCOM, Invisible Inc, Don't Starve, or any game that features permadeath and roguelike randomisation, this game is perfect for you. I would wholeheartedly recommend this game if you enjoy this game style.But if you are not a glutton for punishment and don't enjoy dying a lot, this isn't for you, and I strongly urge you to avoid this game, simply because a lot of the negative reviews I feel are from gamers who don't enjoy this game style.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 12
												(Played this game on the Xbone too, so have significantly more hours than stated)This is definately a gem of a game, although often very difficult and frustrating. You'll probably be on your third playthrough before you actually finish the game (especially if not playing on easy) due to the games strange mechanics and lack of explanation. I feel like this is where all the negatibity comes from.For the majority of the game you will just be playing a squad combat type gameplay. The other part of the game is creating heroes through bloodlines to use in this combat (+to use for a few extras like Sagewrites and Crucibles). Every hero has unique stats and a set class, depending on their parents. Your heroes will age, and die once they get too old. This sounds like a frustrating concept at first, however it really makes you use the bloodlines system, and gives the game alot of depth missing from other squad combat games.Again, I think alot of negativity comes from people not bothering with these mechanics, hitting a dead end, and blaming the game.My issue with this game is ****ing RNGesus. In combat, you have a chance to miss shots (even in Melee) which REALLY frustrates me when everyone in my squad misses a creature and it proceeds to blow my favourite character up. Having said that, maybe the game wouldnt be so addicting if it wasnt for RNGesus. Reccomend this game. 8.5/10.

												I wasn't excpecting to like Massive Chalice as much as I did.The game has a lot to like about it, it's got a decent amount of combat depth and can be played casually through or with more of a challenge on the higher difficulty raitings.The overarching generational breeding and house management game is what really kept me playing.
